Ottawa, January 27, 1944

Mr. J. A. McNeill, Acting Principal, Portage la Prairie,
Indian Residential School, Portage la Prairie, Man.

With reference to the December quarterly Return of the Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School, the Department approves the discharge of Jack Myerion No. 224 from the Portage la Prairie School.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Ottawa, April 26, 1944.

Mr. J. Waite, Indian Agent, Portage la Prairie, Man.

With reference to the March Quarterly Return of the Portage la Prairie Residential School, we note that No. 0368 Elizabeth Perswain is not shown; kindly explain this omission. No. 0243 Grace Merriek and No. 0250 Myrtle Taite are both over sixteen years of age. If you desire to keep these two girls after June, authority must be granted from this office.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
INDIAN RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL

PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE, MAN.

and most of them will just spend the summer sitting around on the reserve. I will be left with two men to do all this work, and one of them is to have three weeks holidays in July. The other one is on his holidays now. We have around forty tons of hay to put up also. It is absolutely impossible to hire a man for farm work in this district, on account of the air ports etc., so that you can see that I am in rather of a predicament if these boys are allowed to go home at this time.

We have the prospects of a wonderful crop. The wheat is heading out already, and is a wonderful stand of grain.

Hoping to hear from you as soon as possible,

I am,
Sincerely,

[Signature]
Principal.

P/S. I would have written about this matter sooner, but it was not until two or three days ago, that I knew this situation was arising.

If you should decide that these boys are to be allowed to go home for July and August, I would ask you to advise me what to do for help, as I have no solution for the problem myself.

Please wire reply.

[Signature]
Mr. Hoey,
Dep. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir,—

We have had a very fine year at the school in Portage la Prairie, and the children are going home in good health and well clothed.

We have had no truancy cases this year and the children on the whole have been quite contented and happy.

It has been the custom in this school for the Principal to keep five of the senior boys through the holidays, to carry on the work of the farm. Last year I paid the boys forty dollars apiece, and took them to the Brandon fair for a day, also the Portage fair for a day, and they go to town Wed. and Sat. evenings to the picture show etc.

This year we plan the same program, except that I am paying them fifty dollars instead of forty, as wages are higher.

We are milking twenty cows now and have more to freshen. All pure bred Jerseys, and the children have been drinking all this milk. During the holidays we take the cream to the creamery and build up a credit for butter.

Last year we threshed around 5000 bushels of grain, filled two silos approx. 100 tons. 1200 bushels of potatoes, and had wagon loads of other vegetables for our own use. We did this work all by ourselves without extra help. We have two men on the staff, and myself. I worked with them as I have had considerable experience on the farm.

This year the Fathers of two of the boys whom I wish to keep, insist that I let them go home, as they need them, and have had a lawyer write to me to that effect, and threatened further procedure.

One Father Thomas Myerson has fifteen acres in crop, and Wallace Petters the other has around seventy-five acres. He believes he has three smaller boys in the school. His boy is sixteen this month.

I have no trouble with the boys staying if the parents would keep out of it. In fact some of them would sooner stay. I have been here almost two years, and have not had a case of smoking or swearing on the premises since I came, so they are pretty fine boys. I do not employ any staff member who smokes. Not that I am bigoted about smoking, but just as policy, to set an example to the children.

I feel that after these boys have been here ten years, they owe something to the school, and that it is not asking too much that they remain for the summer months. Those who were coming back for another year, I gave a months holiday in the fall, after the other children came back.

I have taken this matter up with Mr Waite and also Mr Hamilton. They think the boys should stay, but are not sure of what the law actually is, and advised me to get a ruling from Ottawa on the matter.

If one boy is allowed to go, of course the parents will all want them,

Ottawa, June 26, 1944.

Dear Mr. McNeill:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 24th instant, in which you seek information with respect to the employment of a number of boys, five in all, at the school during the holiday season.

It is noted that the fathers of two of these boys are insisting on the discharge of their sons.

The Minister has power to compel an Indian pupil to attend an Indian day or residential school between the ages of 7 and 16 years. He can, where a pupil displays evidences of waywardness or delinquency, compel such pupil to remain an additional two years. I am convinced, however, that the Minister would not be justified in asking either of these two pupils to remain for an additional two-year period.

It is my hope that you may be able to persuade these boys to remain. The boy who is 16 might be formally discharged and re-employed as a farm hand at the school. Inspector Hamilton, if he has the time at his disposal, might assist you in working out a solution to the problem. I am sending forward a copy of this letter to him.

Yours sincerely,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Mr. John A. McNeill,
Principal,
Indian Residential School,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Hepon Chaski of the Sioux Village refuses to allow his two girls and one boy to return to the Portage la Prairie Residential School. The girls are numbered—0288, Georgina Chaski; 0309 Doreen Chaski; the boy, George Clifford, 252. Aged 13 years, 11 years and 13 years respectively.

The man claimed that the children were poorly fed, that they were abused by the matron—Mrs. McNeill wife of the Principal—and other complaints of a minor nature. I had the Chaski family and the Principal in the office, found that the eldest girl had been working at a cafe in town during the holidays and that most of the complaints were unfounded. I called at the school on several occasions at meal times, and consider the children well-fed. It is my opinion that Chaski and his wife expect the children to work, both the boy and the eldest girl can obtain work without difficulty. The woman especially is against the children attending school and it would appear that the girl and boy would rather work than attend school.

There is no doubt that difficulty will be experienced in having these children return to school. I have interviewed the man on several occasions and he refuses to send them. Before obtaining the services of the R.C.M.P. Police I would be pleased to receive Department advice in this matter.

Memorandum:

DEPARTMENTAL SOLICITOR

Attention: Mr. W.M. Coffey

For your information I attach copy of Indian Agent Waite's letter of October 19 and also a copy of our reply dated October 27. I am also forwarding a copy of a letter dated December 6 received from Agent Waite.

I called at the school on several occasions at meal times, and consider the children well fed. It is my opinion that Chaski and his wife expect the children to work, both the boy and the eldest girl can obtain work without difficulty. The woman especially is against the children attending school and it would appear that the girl and boy would rather work than attend school.

There is no doubt that difficulty will be experienced in having these children return to school. I have interviewed the man on several occasions and he refuses to send them. Before obtaining the services of the R.C.M. Police I would be pleased to receive Department advice in this matter.

MEMORANDUM:

Mr. Roey,

I am in receipt of your memorandum of the 8th instant in connection with the children of Hepon Chaski attending school, to which is attached correspondence from Indian Agent Waite. Before the Magistrate will give judgment in this matter he wishes to be advised on the following points -

1. How does the Department bring the Sioux Indian as an Indian under the meaning of the Indian Act, Section 2, subsection (a)?

2. A statement relative to the Long Plain Sioux Reserve; who holds title to this land or the reserve. In other words how are the Sioux a particular band?

I understand that the Sioux band of Indians, of which Chaski is a member, occupy their own reserve, these lands being purchased by appropriation from the Cree band of Indians upon surrender. In order that these lands can be termed a reserve within the meaning of Section 2 (j) of the Indian Act the lands in question would have to be set apart by treaty or otherwise for the use or benefit of or granted to a particular band of Indians of which the legal title is in the Crown.... If the wording of the vote states that these lands were purchased for the Sioux Indians then in my opinion this land is a reserve within this said subsection and it follows that Chaski is a member of a band of Indians as defined in the Indian Act and, therefore, an Indian.

I do not presume to interpret the law for the Magistrate but would suggest the statements as requested by Indian Agent Waite be sent forward so that he can place them before the Magistrate.

Solicitor.

Dear Sirs:

Having just completed the "Indian R.S. Quarterly Return" for the above school for the quarter ending September the thirtieth I must explain why certain pupils from the Roseau Reserve in the Selkirk agency are shown to have been absent from school during September. I must also add that four children from the same reserve still have not been returned. Three of these come from the Laroque family and are all under twelve years of age. The fourth is Joe Tom a boy of fourteen.

Classes on

The above school opened the Tuesday of the fourth, the day following Labor Day. The whole staff was here to assume the regular duties the last day of August. Everything was in readiness.

The truck that took the Roseau children home at the end of June had been hired to go after them. However Mr. Brad the farm Instructor thought it might be better if he obtained a truck or cars near the Reserve. That I could pay them the amount I had originally planned to pay a man with truck from Portage La Prairie. This was agreed upon. Mr. Brad was able to round up about half the number of children and had them back to school without delay. His intentions were to bring the remainder without delay.

Days passed and I waited expecting each day that the children would arrive. On the twentieth I wrote to him and in his immediate reply he stated- "That reason these children are not back to school is on account of weather conditions. The roads around here have been impossible and these children are over in the states. They cannot get back here and I cannot go for them. As soon as conditions are better I will go after them."

On receipt of the letter part of which I have just copied I phoned Mr. McPherson the agent. In a couple of days another group of children were returned. However there are still the four mentioned above who are still not back.

It is extremely difficult these days to finance the average Indian school and for this reason among others we are
anxious to have our full quota on hand from the beginning. I do not hesitate to say that the failure of the children from Roseau to return to school at the opening date is something that should result in financial loss to the school. All was in readiness for their reception and a way had been provided for their transportation. A principal can do no more.

Trusting that you may consider sympathetically the position of the school in the above matter. Likewise I hope you will urge the return of the four children whose names I have already mentioned from Roseau. I remain,

Yours sincerely,

I would report that at 10:10 a.m. this date, Oct. 26th, 1945, a telephone call was received at this Detachment from the Elie Telephone Operator to the effect that two small Indian boys were at the home of Alphonse RHEAULT, near Elie. These boys had spent the night in a culvert and RHEAULT had taken them in. It was believed that they had run away from a home. I requested the operator to contact Mr. RHEAULT to detain them and proceeded to Elie per Police car 8230.

On arrival at Elie I found that the two boys had escaped from Mr. RHEAULT and were heading East on the C.N.R. tracks. We took pursuit but as soon as the boys saw us, they went North West through the fields. In the meantime, having reported this matter to Station VIGE, I learned from the radio station that the two above named boys had run away from the Indian Residential School, Portage, the previous afternoon. Pursuit continued but we lost the boys. We then picked up their trail South and East of Elie, but again lost the boys. It was again picked up near the cemetery, South and West of Elie and by 12 noon, we again caught sight of the boys running across an open field where we thought we had them cornered against the LaSalle River. They promptly waded through the river up to their waists about one hundred yards ahead of me. I followed them through the river and as they started running from the opposite bank, two local citizens assisting in the search came out of the bush and headed them off. Both boys were captured at 12:15. By this time, Cst. Bailey arrived with police dog Lennie and we conveyed the boys to Portage la Prairie where I handed them over to A.G. Huston Esq., Principal of the Indian Residential School, obtaining a receipt.

The boys stated that they were trying to reach Dominion City as their mother was ill, but this story was later changed and they stated that their mother was in the U.S.A.

Expenses: $2.50, Period Oct. 16th - 31st. .50¢

Dear Mr. Huston:

With reference to your letter of the 14th instant regarding travelling expenses of pupils returning to the Portage la Prairie Residential School, it is noted that you request payment for two trips made by Mr. Brad at a cost of $25.00 and two trips made by Moon's transfer at a cost of $35.00. Owing to present regulations we will have to have a receipt from both of these persons before payment can be refunded to you.

In view of the above, it has been found necessary to again return your account so that receipts and information requested herein can be supplied.

The Rev. Mr. Jones, Principal of the Portage Residential School phoned my home last night and requested permission to bring by plane to Winnipeg six children from Island Lake. I told him it would be necessary to obtain the Department's authority because of two reasons:

1. Transportation costs.
2. Children have not been medically examined.

Mr. Jones stated there were many children on the Reserve without opportunity for education and he felt that those applying should be granted the privilege. Some of the children concerned are related to the late Ewart Monias who taught school at Nelson House.

The cost I am advised by Central Northern Airlines, who service the district, will be as follows: Children, half fare up to 12 years of age. This amounts to $35.15 from Island Lake to Winnipeg. The children could be sent from Winnipeg to the Portage School by special taxi for a total sum of $12.00. Grand total for the six pupils will be $222.90, plus meals and unforeseen expenses.

The plane will be going to Island Lake September 16th or 17th and if permission is granted to bring these children in, I should know at once in order that I may advise Mr. Stevenson, Assistant Agent at Island Lake.

A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies for Manitoba.

Ottawa, September 15, 1947.

Mr. A. G. Hamilton,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
538 Dominion Public Building,
Winnipeg, Manitoba.

We have your letter of the 12th instant, regarding the request of the Principal of the Portage la Prairie Residential School to bring children from Island Lake to his school, by plane. I wish to confirm the following Army Signal sent today:

"Department not prepared to authorize children being brought from Island Lake to Portage la Prairie. Letter follows."

At the present time we have not received any nomination from the United Church of Canada for a teacher for the Island Lake U. C. School, but we are communicating with them again and it is hoped that a teacher will be secured.

As you intimate in your letter, it is doubtful if we should bring children such a long distance without previous medical examination.

In any case, the approval of the Indian Agent should first be obtained before children are sent such a distance to a residential school. Evidently, that has not been done. It is possible that there may be children at Island Lake who require institutional care, but certainly the Indian Agent is the best man to give us that information. It might be well for you to communicate with Mr. Goodman and ascertain from him if there are any children at Island Lake who actually need institutional care. In the meantime, if the school is re-opened there is no reason why the children at Island Lake should not attend it, if their parents are able to look after them.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.

June 30th, 1948.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education,
Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Indian Affairs Branch,
OTTAWA, Ontario.

Dear Col. Neary:

On my recent visit to Norway House, Indian Agent Goodman asked me if I could find employment for Mrs. Stanley Settee in Portage la Prairie, and also suggested that I take into our School her three children. This I have done. The reason for this request was the disruption in the home. Stanley, her husband, has been drinking and when under the influence of liquor threatens his wife with bodily harm. He also requested that his children be placed in my care and stated that he would pay the transportation cost. There may be some difficulty in collecting this money. I am forwarding the account for the transportation of these three children and their mother who had charge of them, for your consideration please. Mr. Goodman will endeavour to collect this sum from Stanley if he remains in constant employment, but if he should be dismissed for his conduct there will be no way of collecting the money.

Mrs. Settee's conduct has been above reproach. She is a good woman, and I have been fortunate in securing a good position near here where she can see her children every Sunday.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones

(Rev.) Joseph Jones

Education Division,

I wish to acknowledge receipt of your letter of July 6th 1948 under file 27-1-10 (E.1) to which was attached copy of letter which you had received from the Rev Joseph Jones, Principal of the Portage la Prairie Residential School.

In this week's mail I forwarded Applications for Admission to the Portage la Prairie Residential School for 3 children of the Settee family namely, Doreen, Stanford, and Frank. Doreen Settee was attending the Brandon Residential School and has now been transferred to the Portage la Prairie Residential School. The father Stanley Settee is responsible for the fares of his wife and Doreen. Fares of Stanford and Frank are payable by the Department and Mr Goodman requested Mr Jones to have the Selkirk Navigation Co submit invoice to this office in triplicate and we would voucher for same.

I do not understand Mr Jones writing the Department with regard to this matter as Mr Goodman guaranteed payment of these fares and Mr Jones should have forwarded the bill to this office as was his understanding with us. Stanley Settee the father has already deposited $30.00 in this office against payment of fares for Doreen & his wife and is quite willing to pay the balance as soon as he knows amount of same.
If the Department will forward account received from Mr Jones we will have the Selkirk Navigation Co submit invoices as described above and will forward by Postal Money Order the fares of Mrs and Doreen Settee.

I trust this clears this matter up to the satisfaction of the Department and also Mr Jones.

Dear Sir:

One of the problems that this office has been meeting with of late is in connection with pupils of Residential Schools.

For instance let us say that a new pupil is admitted to Residential School on the 15th of September with the approval of our Dept. at Ottawa. Your Dept. is then advised of the admission to the Residential School of this child and the allowance is suspended. During the month of October this child runs away from school and returns to her home on the Reserve where she starts attending the Day School regularly.

The problem now, is this child entitled to be re-instated for Family Allowances while she is still considered a pupil of the Residential School. We feel that the Allowance should not be paid until her discharge from the Residential School has been approved by Ottawa and she attends the Day School regularly.

At your earliest convenience would you kindly advise regarding this important procedure.

Yours very truly,

(sgd) D. E. Boyle
for A. G. Hamilton,
Superintendent.
Your letter of December 21st, 1948, file F.A. 3, to the Regional Director of Family Allowances in Winnipeg was referred by Mr. Howden to the National Director of Family Allowances, who in turn referred it to this office for attention.

It is not understood why this matter was referred to Mr. Howden, in view of the fact that Indian Affairs Branch are responsible for the administration of Family Allowances for the Indian population of Canada. If any points arise concerning this administration, they should be referred to Mr. Davis, Regional Supervisor, at Winnipeg, or to this office.

I am enclosing copy of a letter to Mr. Howden, which is self-explanatory, which I hope covers the point raised. Your action in future cases should be to immediately report the circumstances to Indian Affairs Branch Head Office for the attention of the Superintendent of Education, who will then decide whether the child in question should be formally discharged from Residential School or not.

Dear Sir:

Your letter of January 4th, 1949, file No. 11-5-10, to the National Director of Family Allowances has been referred to this office for attention.

It is not understood why the Superintendent of the Portage la Prairie Agency referred this matter to you, as his course is quite plain. It should be referred to our Regional Supervisor in Winnipeg or to this office.

The question raised is one that has occurred quite often since the inception of the Family Allowances Act. If a child is admitted to Residential School with the approval of the Superintendent of Education at Ottawa, the child is considered to be in Residential School until properly discharged. If the child runs away from Residential School, he becomes truant, and the fact that he attends a Day School does not make him eligible for Family Allowances until such time as the case has been dealt with by the Superintendent of Education and the child is properly discharged from Residential School.

Dear Mr. Hamilton:

On Saturday evening, the 26th of January, 1949, four of our senior girls left the school without permission about 7:15 in the evening. Their absence was discovered about 9:15 when the senior girls were going to the dormitory. I immediately phoned to the C.N. Railway to check on the tickets issued to the station at Edwin which is the nearest to the Long Plain Reserve. I also informed the R.C.M.P. and asked them to be on the lookout and the area pulled out and to keep watch on the highways and roads. I also phoned Mr. Russell, your assistant, informing him of the incident and what measures had been taken to find the girls. Then I phoned to Mr. Clarke, the farm instructor at Long Plain, asking him to keep a lookout for the girls. I also phoned to Mr. Grant Lambe of Edwin, who owns a bombardier and had been in Portage that evening, asking if he had seen the girls on the road. He had not seen them but suggested they would travel on the tracks made by his bombardier or on the highway. Mr. Clarke was of the opinion that some of the Indians who had been in Portage that night would pick them up. All these suggestions were very far out. The girls for some unknown reason decided to travel by the river. This was disastrous as the river is subject to overflows and the girls got their feet wet and of course their feet would soon freeze.

On Sunday morning at 10:45 a.m., Mr. Clarke phoned to say that the girls were at Widow Wescoup's place and that their feet were badly frozen. I asked that the girls should be brought in to the hospital right away and I also informed the R.C.M.P. and Mr. Russell. The police went out and found only two of the girls. The other two the others had taken them home. This was a great mistake as it delayed their admission to the hospital. I phoned to Dr. Kettlewell and I believe Mr. Clarke and Mr. Russell did so. I was at the hospital at 2:30 p.m. on Sunday the 30th, when Dr. Kettlewell arrived to attend to the girls. I will leave the Doctor to give you a report of the condition of the girls. The names, ages and numbers of the girls are:

- 0306 Rowena Smoke, 14 years.
- 0307 Pearl Woods, 13 years.
- 0310 Annie Assiniboine, 14 years.
- 0329 Lillian Daniels, 15 years.

Yours sincerely,

(Signed) Joseph Jones.
Everything possible was done to locate the girls and as soon as located they were rushed to the hospital. It was necessary to hire a bombardier to get two. I attach a report submitted by Mr. Jones.

The children stated they were well fed and had no complaints against Mr. Jones or other members of the staff, but they did not like Mrs. Ross.

A.Y. Hamilton,
Superintendent.

February 1st, 1949
Portage la Prairie, Manitoba.

Truancy, Portage School, January 29th, 1949.

I have investigated the truancy of four senior girls from the Portage Indian Residential School which took place Saturday evening, January 29th, 1949. The four girls were Rowena Smoke, 14 years, Pearl Wood, 13 years, Annie Assiniboine, 14 years and Lillian Daniels, 15 years.

I interviewed the girls today in the General Hospital where they are being treated.

Annie Assiniboine gave only one reason. She stated they had planned to run away some days ago because they did not like the matron, Mrs. Ross. On the Saturday afternoon in question, the girls wanted to stay inside and listen to a special program of cowboy music. They said Mrs. Ross refused permission and made them go outside to play and skate. Apparently the girls were cross because they could not have their way and so decided to go home. I would just add here, - Mrs. Ross was sick on Saturday although she may have issued the instructions, she was not on duty.

The complaints from the others for their dislike of Mrs. Ross could be listed as follows:

1. She strikes us on the head with her fist.
2. If we take more than five minutes to do our hair at night she makes us sit on the floor in the corner of the dormitory for one or two hours.
3. She neglects us when she comes on duty and if any are missing she strips us.
4. We are locked outdoors and made to play outside from four to six p.m.
5. If our shoes are worn out we get boys running shoes and sometimes they do not fit.
6. We are not allowed to talk to the boys in school - not even our brothers.
7. If we tear our night-gowns, we are made to sleep in boys clothes - shirt and shorts.
8. We are not allowed to talk at mealtime.

In connection with the complaints, they are explained as follows by Mr. Jones:

1. At times Mrs. Ross rapped on their heads using her knuckles as when rapping on a door.
2. Some girls waste time and play around at night so a stricter time is given. Mr. Jones says five minutes is incorrect.
3. Checking clothes is routine work and apparently some punishment is necessary to check waste.
4. Mr. Jones claims he insists that the children get outside for fresh air. If the weather is nice then they must remain out. The children look well and none had serious colds.
5. Shoes are a big problem and an expensive item. Naturally a half worn out shoe cannot be discarded. The girls do not like running shoes - they want oxfords.
6. Certainly boys and girls cannot wander about the building to visit as they wish. Meetings can be arranged and they skate together on the same rink.
7. Children are often careless and waste cannot be allowed.
8. This is a rule authorized by the Principal.

The route taken to get home was not anticipated by anyone and the parents do not know why they chose the river. It is presumed they figured there was less chance of meeting anyone.
Portage la Prairie,
Manitoba.

Dear Sir:

Re: Lilian Daniel
Rowena Smoke
Pearl Woods
Annie Assiniboine

These four girls were admitted to Portage General Hospital on Sunday, January 30, after having been out all night in cold weather. All four girls suffer from frozen feet and mild degrees of frost bite on the hands.

Lilian Daniel has both feet badly frozen. The feet are badly blistered from the toes half way to the heels. The toes are cyanosed. Although the toes are at present in very poor shape, I feel there is good possibility that she shall have a complete recovery. There is, however, a possibility that she may lose one or more toes due to gangrene.

Rowena Smoke also has both feet badly frozen. Her condition is the least favourable of all four girls. She is more likely to lose one or more of her toes.

Pearl Woods has her left foot severely frozen. The circulation in her toes seems to be improving. There is a good chance that she will have a complete recovery.

Annie Assiniboine froze only a portion of her left foot. Only the outer side of the foot is affected. The only toe involved is the little toe of the left foot. There are signs of early gangrene of this toe. There is only slight possibility that she may lose this toe.

The injuries of all these girls make it impossible to estimate length hospitalization which will be necessary or the possible outcome. I doubt very much if any of these girls will be out of the hospital in less than two weeks. Some of the girls may be there much longer.

Your sincerely,

JK/AP

Re: Portage la Prairie Residential School

Your report has been discussed with the Director, and a copy has been sent to the Reverend Dr. Dorey of the United Church of Canada. The complaints against Mr. Jones have been noted, and it is felt that the repression of these Indian children is, in several instances, undesirable.

The Department has never approved of corporal punishment for Indian pupils except in the event of complete insubordination. Would you please inform the Reverend Mr. Jones immediately of the following instructions:

1. That corporal punishment will be used only where all other methods of disciplining a pupil have failed.

2. That corporal punishment will be administered only on the hands with a proper school strap (regulation 15" rubber).

3. That the maximum number of strokes on each hand in no instance exceed four in number for male pupils of over fourteen years of age and in proportion for boys under that age.

4. That all such corporal punishment be administered in the presence of the principal or by the principal.
5. That a Corporal Punishment Register be maintained at the school containing the following headings:

(a) Date,
(b) Reason for Punishment,
(c) By whom administered,
(d) Witness,
(e) Signature of pupil punished.

6. That this Register be made available for inspection by all Indian Affairs Branch officials visiting the above."

The four girls mentioned above are the ones who ran away from school and had their feet badly frozen. Three are back at school, but are determined to run away again. The parents wish to take them home.

Mr. Jones claims these pupils are now real heroes in the eyes of the other pupils. Annie Assiniboine ran away in December 1948 and was not punished. The parents came to me and requested I ask Mr. Jones not to cut Annie's hair. I saw Mr. Jones and told him about the request. I also added that this type of punishment was not looked on with favor at Ottawa. He said he was going to write and find out if this was correct but when I last saw him, no letter had been sent. Mr. Jones now claims that all this trouble rests on the fact that Annie Assiniboine was not punished by cutting her hair.

The four girls mentioned above nearly lost their lives and even yet are determined not to remain in school. The parents also, are determined to take them home. (2) Would the Department approve a transfer to Brandon if parents agree? (3) Does the Department approve cutting girls hair as a punishment and if so will it be in order for Mr. Jones to use this type of punishment on the four girls concerned?
I feel we assume grave responsibility to keep pupils except under strict guard when they are so determined to leave school. They are not learning anything—they are defiant—and trouble makers. Portage la Prairie Indian Residential School.

Reference your 37-10 of February 21

By this time you will have received our official letters of February 21 concerning conditions at this school. I have noted the comments of the Reverend Mr. Jones with regard to the cutting of the hair of Annie Assiniboine.

The Department has always felt that punishment should vary according to the gravity of the fault, its frequency, the effort to resist it and the temperament of the pupil. The punishment should not be degrading and in effect should not dishonour the child in his own eyes. A degrading punishment which diminishes the child's self-respect or which causes the child to lose the respect which he owes his teacher has no place in Christian education. It is felt that the cutting of a pupil's hair definitely falls in this category and should not be resorted to.

We have always expected that principals and teachers should practice such discipline as may be exercised by a kind, firm and judicious parent in his family. The underlying reason for the corporal punishment regulations outlined in our previous official letter is that in this way teachers can avoid the appearance of indiscreet haste in the discipline of their pupils.
We have never received a letter from Mr. Jones with regard to the disciplining of Annie Assiniboine. I am writing to Dr. Dorey today concerning the parents' request that these children be not sent back to the Portage la Prairie School. We have noted their ages and are prepared to approve their transfer to the Brandon Residential School for the remainder of the term.

Bernard F. Neary,
Superintendent of Education.

Dear Friends,

Indian parents, formerly Roman Catholic, of their own free will desire affiliation with a Protestant group of free non-sectarian churchmen. They desire their child or children who have been pupils in a Roman Catholic dominated residential school, to be admitted into a residential school in charge of personnel of a Protestant Church.

The claim is made that the latter school is not permitted to accept such children. Can you tell me why?

In this country of supposed religious freedom, have these parents no right to decide the school to which they will send their children?

On what conditions can any change be effected? May children leave either a Protestant or a Roman Catholic school at parent's request, and attend the ordinary community public school? On what conditions?

I shall thank you for a considered answer, since I am deeply interested in the welfare of many of these peoples.

Yours in His Service,

H. L. Richardson,
Minister & Missionary,
Churches of Christ.

Dear Col. Neary,

Enclosed is a copy of a letter I received this morning. Ella Bell returned to school September 29. She is a good girl and a fair student in grade VII. She is happy enough as long as her parents and the two older daughters who are at home stay away, but each visit means a crying spell for them all.

I have always understood that a pupil who returns in September remains for all the school year till June 30, whether they become 16 or not. This girl will benefit by being here and if possible I want to keep her.

If I let her go I feel it will create a precedent of which the Indian parents will be quick to take advantage. Can you give me a definite ruling on this matter?

Sincerely Yours,

It has never been our policy to discharge children from a residential school simply because they reach the age of 16 years. If a pupil reaches 16 during the academic year, it has always been our practice to retain such a child in the school until the end of the academic year.

It is considered that Ella Bell should remain in the Portage la Prairie Residential School until the end of June, 1950.

Sincerely yours,

Philip Phelan,

Indian Affairs Branch,
Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

With reference to your letter of November 16, 1949, file No. 576-10 (EL) in which you enclosed a copy of Rev. O. B. Strapp's letter regarding two Indian boys - Victor Bruce and Job White.

Last week I received a telephone call from the Winnipeg Police stating that they had the two above mentioned boys in their custody. On receipt of this advice I telephoned Mr. Strapp to have these boys taken back to the Brandon Residential School. Mr. Strapp stated that he would not come for the boys without a police escort. As the boys were not taken from the detention home I telephoned Mr. McLean, Principal, Portage la Prairie Residential School to come in for the boys. The boys only stayed one night at the Portage School when they returned to the Brandon School. They stayed there one night and were away again in the morning. Up to the present time I have not heard of their whereabouts.

In my opinion these boys are going to continue to roam. One of them does not appear to be any too bright and should never have been sent to a school. I also feel that if these boys had had different treatment when they first entered the Brandon School they would not have started to run away.

I have instructed the police to have these boys picked up again and placed in a detention home at Portage la Prairie until I am able to go north at which time I will return the boys to their reserves.

R. S. Davis,
Regional Supervisor of Indian Agencies.

(ASSISTANCE TO DEPT. OF INDIAN AFFAIRS)

17062

17-11-49.

1. At 2:45 p.m., this date Mr. A. McLEAN, Principal of the Indian School at Portage la Prairie, Man., called at this office and reported that the two above named had run away from the School at about 2:00 p.m., and that he had made a search for them about the City, but without any success, and requested assistance in this regard.

2. Available descriptions are as follows: Victor BRUCE, 14 to 15 years, 5'4"-5", Indian features, wearing blue denim overall pants, cloth jacket with fur collar, cap and rubber boots ankle height. Job WHITE, 14-15 years, 5'0", dark Indian features, wearing blue denim overall pants, blue smock, and cap. Both originally from Norway House I.R., Man.

3. Information received from Mr. NIGGELI, Indian Agent at Portage la Prairie, Man., was that the above named boys ran away from the Indian School at Brandon, Man., on Nov. 2nd, 1949, and that they were located in Winnipeg on 16-11-49, and on 16-11-49 were brought to the Indian School at Portage la Prairie where they received a new issue of clothing, and ran away from here as shown in para. 1 above. In the p.m. of 18-11-49 they reported to the Indian School at Brandon, Man., and left again in the a.m. of 19-11-49.

4. Assistance was given as requested by Mr. McLEAN and patrol about the City of Portage la Prairie, and District was made in company with Mr. McLEAN, via Indian Dept. transport, but no trace of the boys could be found.

5. Complete information is not available from either the Indian School or the Indian Office at Portage la Prairie, Man., but same may be available at Brandon, from where they may have run away in the first instance, and in view of which, extra copies of this report is attached for the information of Brandon Det. and unless other information comes to light, or otherwise instructed, this file will be considered closed at this Det.

Dear Mr Hoey,

May I again respectfully submit for your consideration a request for a Tractor and row crop drill and cultivator. All the implement firms are turning out the ideal outfits for our work here. At all our schools the most important part of our crop is the row crop. Potatoes, field and tabacco, turnips, carrots, parsnips, sugar beets, mangels and peas. This involves a tremendous amount of hoeing and if we do not have the proper equipment it is a never ending task. The heaviest and most important part comes while the children are on holidays.

I have reported the condition of the tractor that we have here, and I will now give you an extract of a letter to the department written by my predecessor Rev. W.R. Wood in June 1935.

"In the matter of farm equipment there is a tractor—a very ancient Rumely Oil-Pull which is still conscripted each Fall and made to furnish power for the threshing. It has, I believe, been used for anything else for some time. The Oil-pull is out of date and requires constant tinkering, and in my judgement should be replaced by an up to date tractor which could be used not only for threshing but for ploughing and other field work and for running a grain crusher."

During the last three four years I have spent a lot money for repairs and oil to keep this worn out tractor running, it cannot be used for field work. May I therefore ask for a grant for tractor and attachmenti row crop drill and cultivator. The cost for tractor, drill and cultivator will be about $1,500.00

There is no Manure Spreader on the farm and this next Summer we shall have over 200 tons of manure to spread on the fields, the cost of Spreader will be about $200.00

May I ask for your best consideration of this urgent need.

Yours sincerely,

Joseph Jones
Ottawa, February 17, 1940.

Dear Mr. Jones:

I have for acknowledgment your letter of the 18th instant, in which you send forward, for departmental consideration, a request for a tractor and row crop drill and cultivator, for use at your school farm.

I must state frankly that there is not even a remote possibility of securing this equipment at any time in the immediate future. Owing to the limited funds at our disposal, we are at this date unable to pay in full the per capita grants to our Indian residential schools and yesterday we notified Dr. Cochrane to this effect. Just what action will be taken in the immediate future to reduce costs at Indian residential schools, I am not in a position to state, but I do feel confident that it will be impossible to secure the money necessary for the purchase of farm equipment. If the time at my disposal will enable me to do so, it is my intention to visit Toronto in the course of a week or so and carefully review the whole matter with the church authorities.

Yours very truly,

R. A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Re: Alleged Theft of Harness, Sec. 286 C.C., Comp. of Joseph JONES, Principal of Indian School - Portage la Prairie, Man.

May 19, 1941

With reference to the above and further to P.C.R. dated 16-6-41 in this connection, I have to report that the complainant Joseph JONES informed this office that he had heard a rumour (the source of which could not be ascertained) to the effect that Jim LANEZ, a probable suspect had sold a set of harness to Pete MARIN, Long Plains Indian Reserve, for $150 some few days ago.

I patrolled per P.C.R. 6065 to the Long Plains Indian Reserve accompanied by Sgt. Andrews, where Pete MARIN was interviewed. He stated that he had purchased a set of old harness from Ed. PACIAS, a halfbreed of Portage, on the 6-6-41. He produced this old set of harness which in no way resembled the set lost by the complainant and further stated that the harness which he had stored in the farm instructor's barn for a couple of years. PACIAS had one other set of harness which was also examined but it did not bear the description of the set stolen.

Mr. SAWYER, farm instructor of the Long Plains Indian Reserve, was next interviewed and stated that Ed. PACIAS had had an old set of harness stored in his barn for two or three years, and on the 6-6-41, Pete MARIN had made a deal by purchasing this set of harness from PACIAS for $150 and the deal was made between the two in his presence and MARIN removed this old set of harness from his barn. It was ascertained through local enquiries that MARIN had purchased this harness from Ed. PACIAS and not from DANIELS as reported by the complainant and this purchase was made sometime before the harness referred to was alleged to have been stolen.

Mr. SAWYER, farm instructor of the Long Plains Indian Reserve, is going to co-operate with this detachment in making enquiries in the reserve from time to time and should he receive any information of value, this office will be notified. A large number of the Indians in the reserve were interviewed and enquiries made by the patrol, but no further information could be obtained.

This matter has been kept in mind by members of the detachment while on patrol in the rural districts and thoroughness of farms working in the fields have been checked but no harness which resembles that lost by the complainant have been observed. The second land stores at Portage have been checked periodically but without result. The Portage la Prairie City Police advise that they have nothing further in this matter.

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

SPECIAL NOTE

SPECIAL NOTE

NOTES ON THE PREPARATION OF THIS RETURN

1. Fill in all the columns of this Return, giving full particulars in the case of each pupil, as called for under the various headings thereof.

2. The columns of the Return should be correctly added and the totals placed at the foot thereof.

3. When, owing to the number of pupils, all the names cannot be included on one sheet of the Return, use another sheet, paging it No. 2, and carry forward all totals, placing them in the proper columns.

4. The Returns must embrace only the quarterly periods ending 31st March, 30th June, 30th September and 31st December, respectively, and should be prepared and forwarded immediately thereafter.

5. No Quarterly Grant will be paid until Returns have been received by the Department.

6. The total number of days in quarter means every day in the quarter, including Saturdays, Sundays and holidays.

7. The aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter means the total number of days in residence of all pupils entered on the Return and is ascertained by adding the column under the heading "Total number of days pupils in residence during quarter".

8. The average attendance of pupils during quarter is ascertained by dividing the "Aggregate number of days pupils in residence during quarter" by the "Total number of days in quarter".

9. The amount per capita grant due for quarter is ascertained by multiplying the "Average attendance of pupils during quarter" by the amount of the quarterly per capita grant. In no case, however, will payment be made for any average attendance in excess of the number of pupils for which grant is allowed.

SPECIAL NOTE

A new number must be given to each pupil upon entrance to the school. On this Return the names of the boys and the girls must be arranged consecutively according to numbers.

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 9th ultimo, with reference to a deduction of $32.00 made from the March quarter grant of the Sandy Bay Boarding School in payment of shirts, tunics, etc., supplied this school.

Reverend Sir,

In further reference to your letter of the 25th ultimo, I beg to say that the cheque for the September quarter grant to the Sandy Bay Boarding School, which the Department mailed you on October 17th, last, has been returned to the Department today by the post office authorities.

CANADA
Ottawa, January 13, 1925.

Reverend Sir,

The December quarter return of the Sandy Bay Residential school has just been received and shows an average attendance of 70 pupils.

As you are aware, grant is allowed at the rate of $140.00 per capita. The total amount, therefore, for the December quarter is (70 x $140.00) is $9800.00.

The manner in which the December quarter return has been computed is as follows:

Principal (70 pupils @ $140.00 each) ........................................... $9800.00
Less overpayment September qr. .................................................. -427.50
Balance due ...................................................................................... $9372.50

Rev. Peres Oblates (70 pupils @ $5. each) ........................................... $350.00
Less overpayment September qr. .................................................... -10.00
Balance due ....................................................................................... $340.00

The reason for the above deductions is that when the September quarter return was received it showed an average attendance of 70 pupils, but, through error the grant was paid at the rate of $165.00 per capita instead of $140.00 per capita. The detailed statement of the manner in which the September quarter grant was paid is as follows:

Principal .......................................................................................... $2527.50
Rev. Peres Oblates ............................................................................. $360.00

The same amount should have been paid for the September quarter as for the December quarter but, through the mistake mentioned, an overpayment of $427.50 was made to you and also an overpayment of $10.00 to the Revs. Peres Oblates. These overpayments are being deducted from the December quarter grant and cheques for the balances due will be forwarded under separate cover.

The Department regrets the error made in computing the September quarter grant but I trust that this letter will fully explain the matter.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Rev. O. Chagnon, C.M.I.,
Principal,
Sandy Bay Residential School,
Marius, M.A.N.

Portage La Prairie, Man.
October 16th, 1929.

W.M. Graham Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Re Sandy Bay Residential School.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I submit herewith my report of an examination of the books of the above school which I visited for that purpose October 15th.

The Principal Rev. Father Chagnon produced all the books and records which I asked for including Bank Pass Book, cancelled cheques, and invoices etc. He informed me that an audit of the books had never been made before he accepted that he had not closed up his books since the close of the fiscal year March 31st. It would have taken some considerable time to complete the entries for the past six and a half months so all I could do was to examine the previous fiscal period, April 1928 to March 1929.

A synoptic cash book is used, supplied by the Department and all entries were neatly entered and totalled, the particulars being quite clear and understandable. The Bank Pass Book supplied by the Banque Canadienne Nationale had not been written up since June, so I could not verify the bank balance, but according to the cheques issued since that date and the quarterly grant received in July, the balance at present is $176.49.

The cheque for the last quarter is expected about the 20th October, and Father Chagnon assured me that all bills for goods and salaries had been paid up to date and that practically no indebtedness existed. According to the invoices on file and the statements rendered by wholesalers in Winnipeg for groceries, shoes, and clothing materials etc., and by the cheque stubs, this appeared to be correct.

When examining the cancelled cheques I noticed one for $380.00 in favour of Rev. J.P. Magnon O.M.I. Winnipeg, and later several others for the same amount, and after looking back to the 1927 and 1928 cancelled cheques found others for $395.00. These appeared to have been paid at regular intervals soon after the quarterly grant was received from the Government.

I asked the Principal who Rev. Fr. Magnon was and he informed me that he was the Treasurer of the Oblate Fathers Order in Winnipeg.

I looked through the Synoptic Cash Book, but could find no trace of these cheques having been entered, and asked the Principal how it was, and after I told him that I could not make the totals of the various columns agree with the cheques issued, he stated that the cheques in question were not shown and were an assessment or tax made by the Order, on the number of children in attendance, or in other words a tax on the grant every quarter in order to create a fund to pay deficits of this school or any other school in the jurisdiction of the Order.

This works out at about $21.75 per pupil per annum, or $5.45 per quarter, or 14% of the grant, a rather considerable item of $1,920.00 per annum.

The totals of the different classifications of the Synoptic did however, agree with his figures in the annual statement as submitted to Ottawa, yet I was at first puzzled about the various receipts not appearing in the cash book, so after a little prequestioning I was told that the revenue from Farm & Garden was only estimated at $75.00 per month making the $900.00 in statement for the year, but that it might be more. Then this together with other sources of revenue not shown would make up approximately the above mentioned sum subscribed to the Order.

This other revenue apparently consists of the sale of candies, pork raised on farm, flour purchased wholesale and sold at a profit to Indians in the neighbourhood, and the sale of rabbitkins and other animals etc.

A detailed audit was not made as it would have taken considerable time, and many of the expenditures are bulked and cheques shown in total, then items purchased for staff and neighbouring Indians, from T. Eaton & Co. and other places would have to be recorded, deducted from their salaries, and separated in the Bank a/c and cancelled cheques.

It was some satisfaction however to obtain the above information as it explains to some extent why I have been unable to reconcile the book figures at other schools, with the figures shown in the various annual statements submitted to Ottawa, and then again I have not always been given access to the cancelled cheques and Bank Pass Book, as at Alexander School.

Attached is a copy of the Receipts & Expenditures for the last fiscal year, as the book figures show, but I think you will agree that in view of the above facts it hardly represents a true accounting.

The item for clothing is low, most of it being made at the school by the Sisters, it works out to only $14.74 per pupil a year, and compares very favorably over other schools.

The food cost is high $58.36 per pupil, but Father Chagnon states that in the winter time many outside Indians are fed who appear in bad circumstances and he finds it hard to turn them down when they beg for food, this accounts for the high expenditure to some extent.

The deficit of $331.98 shown as re-imbursed by the Order can be practically discounted as it is less than one quarters contribution to the Order.

The statement of cost of operation attached shows that based on 70 pupils as an average attendance for the year, the average cost per pupil per day is 49.8 cents compared with the amount allowed by per capita grant of 42.4 cents. When given a copy of the cost of operation the Principal appeared very much interested and said he was going to keep it before him and see if he could not reduce the costs for the current year.

In summing up and allowing for the questionable matter of the assessment to the Order, addall revenue not being shown on books, it would appear that the school is ably managed insofar as it concerns
as it concerns close buying, discounts taken from wholesalers, making additional revenue and various other economies etc.

The Principal volunteered the information that there were 65 cattle, 21 horses, 150 poultry, 65 pigs. Wheat 375 bushels, Oats 1100 bushels, compared with 2500 of Barley and 2500 of Oats last year, the wheat and oats will be used for feed, and with 500 bushels of potatoes and other root vegetables he will have sufficient for another year.

The decrease in feed grains is accounted for by hail and dry weather and in view of this feed shortage the Principal will have to buy feed, and as a consequence he intends informing the Order that he will be unable to make the usual contribution or assessment for this year, that is from the last quarter.

The following statements in duplicate accompany this report:

List of Staff-Occupations-Salaries.
Cost of Operation for last Fiscal Year.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

H.B. Rayner.

Re: Sandy Bay Residential School

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit herewith a report of an examination of the records at the above school, which I visited September 25th.

The Principal, Rev. O. Chagnon, O.M.I., produced the cash book, cancelled cheques, Bank Pass Book, and a number of invoices and vouchers for goods purchased, which I proceeded to examine, and if possible verify with the book record.

The period which I examined was from October 15th, 1929, to May 31st, 1930, the book not being written up after that date. The Bank Pass Book had not been sent to the Bank since April 17th, and the cancelled cheques available were to the same date.

According to the Synoptic Cash Book, the balance on hand as at May 31st., was $560.70, and according to Pass Book to April 17th., the balance in Bank Canadian Nationale, Winnipeg, was $3,779.02.

When I was here last year I prepared a statement covering the fiscal year ending March 31st., 1929, as the books were written up to that date, so I have prepared another statement for the fiscal year ending March 31st, 1930.

I also mentioned in my report of last year the nature of certain entries in the cash book, the payment of cheques to religious institutions, also the manner in which the records were kept, and the inability of anyone to make a detailed audit. I regret to report that the same conditions exist, and the cash book cannot be checked with cancelled cheques, deposits or invoices, nor any other supporting voucher or record which was available. It appeared to me that another book or record must be kept in order to keep track of certain items for which cancelled cheques had been returned from the Bank, but which did not appear in the cash book.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.

Another matter which was puzzling included the entries of employees' and staff salaries each month in the cash book, but for which the cancelled cheques did not appear, nor the corresponding entries in the Pass Book.

The Principal was questioned about these and other matters, and after a somewhat lengthy yet amiable conversation, the following information was obtained:

The staff are paid, or at least entries are made, each month in the cash book, according to the rates shown on attached list of salaries. In some cases no cheque is issued, and the money lies in the Trust Account, although entered as paid in the cash book. In other cases a cheque is drawn for half or a portion of an employee's salary, or if several months have gone by, two months' salary will be drawn, but as the entries for each month have been made previously at the monthly rate, the amount of cheque paid is not shown.

This same employee may have ordered personal goods from a mail order house, and the Principal pays the C.O.D. amount from the Trust Account by a cheque. He then records this in a private book, deducts the amount from the employee's salary, and shows the sum as received in "Revenue from other sources", which items (on financial statement) give an inflated idea of miscellaneous revenue for the school.

In another instance, and there are many such, voluntary contributions are made by the staff, including the Principal and Sisters, to their Church institutions and organizations. If they have some credit in the Trust Account, consisting of salaries not drawn, the total of these contributions is computed, and a cheque drawn in favour of the Institution or the official handling the finances. This sum will, of course, appear in the pass book, the cancelled cheque will be returned from the Bank, but no entry made in the cash book.

These and many other items were drawn to the attention of the Principal, and I gathered 15 or 20 such cancelled cheques, totalling about $1500.00 which could not be traced to the cash book. Some were for religious services, payable to the Church officials concerned, others to Rev. P. Magnon, O.M.I., executive of the Oblate Fathers, Winnipeg, Rev. Monmandin, O.M.I., Rev. Prachet, O.M.I., The Brother Director of the College of Sacred Heart, The Oblates Missionaries S.C., St. Boniface Hospital, Winnipeg, and the Sisters of St. Joseph.

In some cases the Principal had forgotten the details concerning the expenditure of these items, and this is natural, as considerable time had elapsed. However, the following explanation will be sufficient to show that although upon first examining the records the procedure appears irregular, the explanation is reasonable, but leaves the whole matter, from an accounting point of view, open to criticism.
Auditor Rayner's Report on Sandy Bay Residential School

I explained this to Father Chagnon, and pointed out the difficulty and embarrassment that would be experienced if questions were asked after a lapse of time, regarding certain items appearing on the books, as well as those omitted.

He admitted that he had been careless unintentionally, and had no experience in keeping books and had followed what to him was the natural thing to do, also that he was kept very busy and could not devote much time to the books.

I understand the school is situated on land belonging to the Church, and that as the stock and some of the farming implements were supplied by the same body, it is expected that some assessment or revenue be obtained from the school to go toward a central fund.

These matters were discussed with Father Chagnon, and I suggested to him a few changes in his book-keeping methods which I thought would be easier for him to follow, as well as anyone who might wish to check or examine the books. These included numbering all cheques and records; the exact amounts in the cash book; that members of staff be paid in full each month; and a cheque drawn for the exact amount of salary, if private purchases of goods from outside be made by the staff, to have them arrange such matters themselves and eliminate showing the payments as revenue to the school, and having to keep track of salary deductions, and when contributions were made to Church Institutions by the staff, such items should not go through the Trust Account, but be remitted direct from the staff themselves.

I also drew up a specimen Bank Adjustment to enable a reconciliation between cash book and pass book, and left it with the Principal. I told the Principal that the Department was not concerned as to the disposition of the staff salaries after they were paid, but that where expenditure appeared as going through the Trust Account from the Government Grant in favour of various institutions, not concerned with the buying of goods, clothing, food, or material for the school or pupils, then such items were open to question and appeared irregular. Father Chagnon appeared impressed with this when it was pointed out to him, and stated that he would arrange things differently and hoped to have the books in better shape in the future.

Although I do not consider the attached statements as correct, they will give an approximate idea as to the business of the school for the last fiscal year.
Auditor Reyner's Report on Sandy Bay Residential School.

The item $1,025.00 - "Proceeds from Farm & Garden" under "Receipts" is misleading, as practically nothing was sold excepting a little meat, from this source. It consists chiefly of profit derived from miscellaneous goods, such as groceries, flour, candles, tobacco, etc., purchased wholesale and sold to Indians on the adjoining reserves at a profit.

As pointed out above, the item "Proceeds from other sources" $815.00 is really payments by the staff for the purchase of their personal needs. The $100.00 is the allowance received for the use of the school as a post office.

From the book figures, at the close of March 31st, last there was a deficit of $678.41, which the Principal assured me would be met by the Church authorities.

Compared with the previous fiscal period, the cost of operation shows a slight increase, for instance, cost of operation per pupil per day was 52.7 cents, compared with 49.5 cents. Clothing was $16.82, and previously $14.74. Cost of food was lower being $46.77 per pupil for the year, compared with $58.36.

Salaries as per list total $4,515.00 as at Sept. 25th., 1930.

A plentiful crop of vegetables and potatoes is on hand also plenty of grain feed and fodder, and although the grain crop has been good this past season, prices do not encourage sales.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I am enclosing herewith a report of an audit made at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, and I regret to inform you that there has been no change in the manner in which these books are kept, although the Auditor took a great deal of trouble to show the Principal how the work should be done, and I have also had correspondence with the Department on the subject.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I have the honour to submit herewith a report of an examination of the records at the above Indian School which I visited August 25th, while at this Agency.

You will recall that last year I made a somewhat lengthy and detailed report (under date of September 30th.) on the condition of the books and the manner in which the school's business transactions were recorded, and I believe you wrote the Dept., concerning the matter.

Insofar as the conditions found upon this visit, my report of last year could be duplicated, as the same situation exists, so my remarks in the report apply just the same at present.

The Principal produced all the records in use, cash book, cancelled cheques, Bank Pass Book, and a number of invoices and vouchers for goods purchased, which I examined and attempted to verify with the books.

The period examined was the last fiscal year ending March 31st., as the book was written only to that date. The Pass Book had been written up to Aug. 11th. and the cancelled cheques returned to July 31st.

The statements attached cover the above period, but I would not care to vouch for their accuracy, as revenue appears in the cash book which is not recorded in the Pass Book; cheques or expenses appear on the Pass Book which have not been entered in the cash book and vice versa.

To make a detailed audit was of course impossible as no Bank Adjustment or reconciliation of cash book and pass book could be made.

The Principal, Rev. O. Chagnon, O.M.I., admits that he does not know how to keep books properly, and does considerable 'estimating' when making entries for certain items, for instance the item shown under "Receipt" as 'refunds for goods from salaries' is just an estimate of what he buys for or sells to the staff or the Indians, and what he deducts from salaries or for which he makes collections.
The statement enclosed is one compiled from the cash book by computing all the totals of the various headings for each of the twelve months, and agrees with statement which was sent the Dept., at the fiscal year end, but very few cheques could be verified with the expenses shown, and there was nothing to show where the revenue other than the grants had been accounted for. Many payments are made in cash as the distance to a banking town is considerable.

The balance for the year ending March 31st., shows a deficit of $455.20 but the Bank Pass Book shows a credit balance of $1,361.32 at same date, but the difference is not accounted for by unpresented cheques.

I think this can be explained the same as last year, as the Principal confirmed it; cheques for salaries are not issued for certain members of the staff, but they are charged up and appear in the cash book.

To offset the surplus thus created, quarterly cheques are made in favour of Rev. P.P. Magon, O.M.I. of St. Boniface, amounting to $350.00 per quarter totalling $1,400.00 which absorbs the salaries of the Principal's and Vice Principal's within $100.00 per annum.

The same thing occurs with the salaries of the Sisters as some cheques were noticed for Rev. Soeurs Notre Dame des Missions, Quebec.

All these matters were again taken up with the Principal and a similar conversation, as outlined in my previous report took place.

Among several suggestions made to him, was that he pay all salaries in full - deposit the ones referred to above in another Bank account, and then draw cheques for the St. Boniface institution from that account, thus eliminating their appearance in the school records, and through the Trust Account, in which the per capita grant is kept.

Specimen Bank Adjustments were left with him showing how the cash book could be balanced with pass book, whether there was a deficit or a surplus, as he did not know how to proceed when an adverse balance occurred at a month end.

The statements attached are self explanatory and contain a comparison with the previous fiscal year in regard to the cost of operation; Receipts & Expenditures and Staff and salaries are also enclosed.

The methods practiced as outlined are I think the result of lack of accounting knowledge, rather than intentional, or an attempt to show misleading information on the books.

I have the honour to be, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

H.B. Rayner, Auditor.
Sir:-

I am enclosing herewith a report of an audit made at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School by Mr. Rayner on the 25th instant, and I regret to say that matters in connection with the keeping of the books and giving an account for the disposition of monies have not improved in the least at this institution. Personally, I think this is a very serious matter. If these funds are intended to be spent for the benefit of the children in the school there should be a proper record kept. I would ask the Department to take steps to see that something is done. It is absurd for the Principal to excuse this state of things by saying that he knows nothing about keeping books. Surely he has some member of his staff who could attend to the work if he cannot do so himself.

Your obedient servant

Ottawa, September 8, 1931.

Reverend Sir:

Mr. Rayner, departmental Auditor, has reported on the financial management of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, and it appears he found it difficult to make a thorough audit because of the present lack of system in keeping the school's financial records. If you, yourself, are not competent in this type of work, surely there is someone on the staff to whom it can be entrusted, and the Department would appreciate it very much if you could arrange to have your records in good form in future.

I understand that Mr. Rayner suggested that you pay all salaries of those in Holy Orders, including the Sisters, into a special bank account and then draw cheques in favour of the Oblate Order or the Sisters of Notre Dame from it. As I have informed Mr. Rayner, this is not necessary, as it is with the Department's knowledge that certain salaries are not paid to the individuals but to the Order from which they come. This is quite proper if the school's finances can stand the charge, and there is no reason why such payments should not appear in your school records. You might have them read "Principal's salary for such and such a period, paid to the Order", etc.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Ottawa, September 8, 1931.

Sir:

I have your 208-11 of the 31st ultimo, with reference to the financial management of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School and Mr. Rayner's report in this connection. The Department is writing to Father Chagnon, in an effort to have better records kept at this school. I wish to refer to one of the suggestions Mr. Rayner made to the Reverend Principal, viz.: "That he pay all salaries in full - deposit the ones referred to above in another bank account and then draw cheques -- from that account, thus eliminating their appearance in the school records." The Department does not concur in this proposal. It is a known fact and is accepted by the Department that at some Indian residential schools which are managed by religious Orders the salaries of members of the Order are paid, at least in part, to the Order itself. Such payments should, quite properly, appear in the school records and they might be entered as "Principal's salary, paid to the Society", or "Sisters' salaries, paid to the Society". If the Department insisted on all salaries being paid in full to these religious workers, deficits would then occur more frequently than in the past. At the present time, if the school's finances are not in good condition, certain members of Orders on the staff are not paid in full. Please inform Mr. Rayner.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Regina, Sask.
