Sir:

I have the honour to submit herewith a report of an examination of the books at the above Indian School, which I visited Oct. 3rd, in accordance with letters from the Department dated June 29th and July 8th. - File No. 125/1/3.

The period under review covered the past fiscal year, and also the first five months - April to August - of the current fiscal year, continuing from the period examined when I last visited the School in August, 1931.

The Principal produced all the records available, including cash book, cancelled cheques, Bank Pass Book, and a few invoices and vouchers for goods purchased, but which by no means covered all purchases, as invoices are not always obtained, I was told, and much is paid by cash instead of cheque.

To a considerable extent, my two previous reports still apply as to the practices followed, and to the condition of the books at this school. It is quite impossible to reconcile the Cash Book with the Bank Pass Book, or make a detailed audit, owing to the "estimated" sums of cash receipts and expenses which are entered as cash items; also expenses entered twice; cash loans to employees shown as salary expense in addition to regular salary amounts of loans due and not paid, shown as cash receipts for one month, and then in the following month after a payment has been made and the loan reduced, the balance due is again shown as a cash receipt.

In this way receipts become inflated and do not represent an accurate accounting. In some cases cheques, varying in size from $100 to $40, will be drawn and cashed, and shown under miscellaneous expense, then some of those expenses paid in cash will be reclassified and shown as expenses again under the respective expense headings, thus expenditures are inflated, and discrepancies occur with Pass Book.

Another practice followed is to make an advance (in cash) to an employee on account of salary before the month end; this is not shown at the time, but when salaries are paid by cheque, the amount previously advanced is deducted and the balance paid, but the full amount of salary is entered in the cash book. The result is that part of that employee's salary

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
has been paid in cash and charged under "Miscellaneous" and yet the full amount of salary is shown under "Salary expense, and the actual cheque issued does not correspond with the book entries.

It is such methods as outlined above which cause endless adjusting and correcting entries for anyone who has to audit or attempt to reconcile the cash book with bank book. Also to obtain the above information it entails much questioning of the Principal who has to rely on memory of what happened, and one feels that although some actions can be traced, there may be others which the books do not disclose.

For instance, after further questioning and observation I found that considerable bartering is done by the School with the Indians, and which contributes to the muddled condition of the records. An Indian will bring a load of wood for fuel purposes; the Principal will exchange for that some beer, flour or groceries, etc., then make an entry in the cash book under "Fuel" expense for the market value of the commodity, yet no cash transaction has taken place - thus, as cattle beefed for food consumption are not shown as revenue, another form of discrepancy is created in the cash book.

I have reason to believe that the same applies to game, such as moose meat, deer, wild fowl and fish, in order to vary the menu at the school.

The isolated location of the school lends itself to such action, coupled with a spirit of helpfulness on the part of the Principal for the Indians.

The Principal admits he is a poor bookkeeper, and dislikes the task of recording details of the school's business, and always gets confused when making entries in the books which are not straightforward transactions, and thus gets involved.

Although specimen Bank adjustments and examples of entries have been left with the Principal together with written instructions, both on this visit and previously, he seems unable to adapt himself to them or follow them out correctly, and I feel after four annual visits to the school, that it certainly requires the services of someone who has a working knowledge of accounting, if the records are ever going to be kept accurately.

The attached statements are submitted for what they are worth. They can be only considered approximate, as the balances shown differ greatly from those appearing on the books, after many errors were found and adjusted. Also in view of the foregoing inaccuracies. It will be noted that the balances on hand are for each period less than what appears in the Trust Account by the Bank Pass Book, yet these differences are not accounted for by unpresented cheques.
It would appear as if expenses had been curtailed considerably the past year, compared to previous years, as the cost of operation shows that actual expenses are practically the same as the amount of Government grant. One factor which has helped the Principal in his financing is the increased per capita grant, which was $155.00 prior to April, 1931, and which was increased the last quarter from $160.00 to $165.00.

The Principal informed me that cheques drawn during September would about absorb the balance shown in Bank as at August 31st. - $799.52, so, as he had no accounts payable to amount to anything, he was awaiting the July-Sept. grant to pay for the ensuing quarter's expenses, which is a fair position compared to some schools, who find themselves in the position of paying the quarter's expenses for which the grant is paid. In other words, the grant is spent before it is received.

I was informed the grain crops had been fair,- 200 bushels of wheat, 1500 of oats, and 150 barley, which will take care of the requirements of livestock. There were also ample root vegetables for the school's requirements, but the potato crop had been poor, owing to insects and lack of rain; only 200 bushels were gathered, so purchases will have to be made later.

The livestock consists of 60 cattle, many of which will be beefed for consumption; 50 hogs, 100 poultry and 18 horses.

From casual observation on the 75 pupils in attendance at present appeared healthy and well nourished, and the school both inside and out appeared clean and tidy.

Although throughout the period examined, the records were found in poor shape and hard to follow, I feel the cause is inconsiderate book-keeping on the part of the Principal, rather than any intention to misrepresent the transactions of the school's business, as all questions asked were willingly answered, and much information freely given.

Reverend Sir:

Mr. Rayner, departmental auditor, has reported on the financial management of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School.

It appears that he again found it difficult to make a thorough audit because of the present lack of system in keeping the school's financial records. The Department considers that it is quite important to have complete records of the financial business conducted at all residential schools. If you have not the time to devote to this detail, it is believed that there must be someone on the staff to whom the work could be entrusted. This matter was brought to your attention by official letter of September 8, 1931, but, apparently, no improvement has yet been effected. The Department would appreciate if you would make immediate arrangements to have your financial records kept in good form in future.

Mr. Rayner advises that specimen bank adjustments and examples of entries have been left with you, together with written instructions. If you communicate with him, I am certain that Mr. Rayner will be pleased to give you any other assistance that you require.

The Department will be interested to hear from you that the arrangements requested in this letter have been made.

Dear Mr. Allen:

I submit herewith a report of my examination of the books at the above Indian School, which I visited August 28th, while at the Portage La Prairie Agency.

The distance from Portage to Sandy Bay is about 70 miles, but I completed the work late in the evening, in order to return to the Agency the same day.

The period under review covered eleven months, ending July 31st., continuing from the time of my previous visit, when I examined the books to August 31st, 1932.

The Principal, Rev. Father Chagnon, O.M.I., always makes me quite welcome, and he furnished me with all the records, including Cash Book Synopsis, cancelled cheques, Bank Pass Book, and some invoices for goods purchased which by no means covered all purchases, as invoices are not always obtained, I was told, and much is paid by cash, instead of cheque.

The Principal admits that he is no bookkeeper. He dislikes working on the books, and has experienced considerable difficulty in recording transactions, which has made it hard to follow when examining the books, and if the figures shown in the books were taken at their face value it would not reflect what has actually taken place.

I have mentioned these matters in previous reports, and the practices followed still apply, although examples and written instructions have been given to the Principal from time to time.

"Estimated" sums of cash receipts and expenses, including garden and dairy produce consumed by the school, have been included as cash items, whereas they are only approximate market price valuations of what the farm and garden produced.

I have informed the Principal that only cash transactions should be shown through the Cash Book, and the Department are well aware that the farm products are consumed, and help in the operation of the school.

Another way in which inflated receipts and expenses occur is by the showing of salaries to employees in total at each month end, and also entering as expenses, advances on their salary before the same month end, although the net amount of salary only is paid. Then, it appears to be the practice for certain of the married employees to take meat, groceries, and farm and garden produce in lieu of salary. Sometimes he shows such a transaction by writing an amount of the salary paid, less the value of the goods, which is also shown as a receipt. In order to make a true accounting of such transactions I suggested that he show such employees' salaries.

N. C. Allen, Esq.,
Representative of the Treasury,
Dept. of Indian Affairs
Ottawa.

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6276, file 584-3, part 1)
salaries by making two entries, one of which would be the actual balance of cash paid, and the other the amount or the goods purchased, the total of which would be the equivalent of the man's salary. Then, by a cross entry show the amount of goods purchased under the heading of "Receipts", but not as cash.

The Principal has with him Mr. G. Schmidt (son of C.P. Schmidt, Agent, Duck Lake), and as he is acting as Disciplinarian at the school in the Boys' Department, and is anxious to learn a little elementary book-keeping, he will, in future, keep these records, and I hope they will be more satisfactory.

Many adjustments and corrections were made throughout the period, insofar as it affected transactions as described above, and a statement of Receipts and Expenditures was prepared and reconciled with the Bank Account, as shown on Statement No. 1.

Total receipts appear as $9,482.67, although the period of eleven months includes only per capita grant for three quarter periods. The per capita grant cheque for the June quarter was received from the Department the first week in August, amounting to $2629.69. The item of $552.07 consists of the previously mentioned goods sold in lieu of salaries to employees, and the goods sold for actual cash amounted to only $31.00.

Expenses show a considerable reduction from previous years. Reductions have been effected in salaries, clothing and shoes, house equipment, farm and garden expense, and although a deficit of $20.50 is shown as at July 31st, it is accounted for by outstanding cheques of $706.64, which would not be charged to the Bank Account for some considerable time after the per capita grant cheque was deposited.

The Principal informed me that no accounts payable, of any consequence, were due at July 31st., so it appears as if his financial position is fairly good, in that he is now financing on the June quarter grant, and so is practically a quarter period ahead.

The cost of operation does not indicate a very fair comparison to previous periods, as the average cost per pupil per day had to be estimated for eleven months, (334 days), whereas the grant was received for 273 days only, according to the figures shown on the financial statement, but substantial reductions are apparent when taking into consideration the difference of one month between this statement and the previous one.

The average number of pupils in attendance throughout last year was 75. 68 were in attendance when I visited the school, and about eight or nine had not returned from holidays.

The list
The list of staff occupations and salaries as at August 28th, amounted to $4,923.50, whereas it will be noted that the actual salaries paid for the eleven months period amounted to only $2,334.00.

The Principal and Asst. Principal hardly ever draw their salaries, but I noticed from the cancelled cheques and entries which are included in the miscellaneous item, that $1141.00 was remitted to the Oblate Order at St. Boniface. This, I understand, represents part of the salaries of the two Oblate Fathers.

The Principal informed me that the live stock on hand at present includes 60 head of cattle, 15 horses, 50 hogs, and about 75 poultry.

The Farm and Garden crops matured early, and harvesting was completed when I visited the school. The crop returns are as follows - 1500 bushels oats; 1500 bushels barley, 100 tons of hay and green feed, and there are ample potatoes and root vegetables for the requirements of the school.

To give you an idea of how involved the bookkeeping appears at this school, after some questioning I found that considerable bartering is done by the Principal with the Indians, which contributes to the muddled condition of the records. An Indian will bring a load of furs for rations etc., the Principal will exchange for that some beef, flour or groceries, etc. Then, he will attempt to make an entry in the Cash Book under "fuel expense" for the market value of the commodity given in exchange, when no cash transaction has taken place. Thus, as cattle beefed for food consumption are not shown as revenue another form of discrepancy is created in the Cash Book. I have reason to believe that the same applies to game, such as moose meat, deer, wild fowl and fish, in order to vary the menu at the school. The isolated location of the school lends itself to such action, together with a spirit of helpfulness on the part of the Principal for the Indians on the adjacent reserve, as they have had a somewhat lean time during the past few years.

From casual observation, the sixty odd pupils in attendance at present appeared healthy and well nourished, and the school, both inside and out, was clean and tidy.

Dear Mr. Allen:

I submit herewith, in duplicate, a report of an examination of the books at the above Indian school, which I visited on November 7th and 8th. The period examined covered one year dating from August 1st, 1933 to July 31st, 1934.

The cash received entries were compared to the deposits in the Bank Pass Book, and the cancelled cheques to the expense entries in the cash book. A bank reconciliation statement was then prepared, from which it will be noticed that the school had a financial deficit of $238.69 as at July 31st, 1934.

During the past year or more the books have been neatly kept by Mr. G. Schmidt, a member of the staff, but since his leaving the school at the end of June, the Principal has attempted to do this work. I found a vast difference in the appearance of July and August entries - in fact, I re-wrote the transactions for those months and offered the Principal suggestions which might show improvement in his recordings.

Invoices were compared by test to various entries, and the additions and extensions were proven also by test.

The revenue for the period was analysed and is set forth on Statement No. 2. It consists principally of the Government per capita grants, amounting to $10,518.76. Although the quarterly grant for June this year was not received until August, the revenue for the period examined contains four quarterly grants.

The expenditures totalled $11,400.31, the larger items of expense being salaries of $3,315.98, food $1,964.86, and miscellaneous items of $2,242.19. The Principal's attention was drawn to the miscellaneous expenses and to the need of a more definite classification of the same under the proper columns in the cash book.

The statement of "Costs of Operation" is self-explanatory, the figures being based upon an expenditure of $11,400.31 and an average attendance of 76 pupils.

The salaries of the staff total $6,233.50, which is a slight increase over salaries a year ago. A few changes have taken place in the personnel of the staff, Brother S. Heytens being taken on as a fireman, while

The livestock, I was informed, consists of 14 horses, 60 cattle, 50 pigs, and about 80 poultry.

Crops this year include 350 bus. wheat, 300 bus. oats, and 200 bus. barley. With a quantity of feed left over from last year, the principal expects to have sufficient to feed the stock.

About 400 bus. of potatoes were raised, but the school will have to purchase more, which, with quantities of cabbages, turnips and other vegetables grown at the school, will supply their needs.

No large outstanding accounts are owing, the debts of the school being those of local merchants for monthly purchases.

From casual observations, the pupils appear to be well clothed and fed. The school building was comfortably warm, clean and tidy.

April 20, 1949.

Mr. W. Gowans,
Supt. of Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Manitoba.

The March Quarterly Return for the Sandy Bay Residential School has been received and noted.

On calculating the grant for the quarter, it is noted that the average attendance of pupils during the quarter was 161.8%, and the total enrolment was 182 pupils. The authorized enrolment for the school is only 150 pupils.

The Principal should be advised that, although the grant for March will be paid on the average of 161.8%, he should make other arrangements for September as the Department can not pay grant on any portion of the average over the authorized enrolment.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Education Division.

July 9, 1952.

Mr. J.H. Staunton,
Supt., Indian Agency,
Dauphin, Man.,

The Auditor-General's Office has checked previous quarterly returns for the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School and brought certain errors to our attention:

(a) The Principal has claimed 62 days grant for pupil 323 and has shown in the Remarks Column "attending day school". As this pupil was not attending the Sandy Bay school during the previous month of June, 62 days grant can not be allowed. This means that the school was overpaid 62 days for this pupil.

(b) The Principal has claimed 92 days grant for pupils 342, 0322 and 0341; however, it is noted that these children were not in residence during the previous June and the first two had returned to the school in September after a lengthy absence. In view of this information the school was overpaid 186 days for the three pupils.

From the information contained in the previous two paragraphs it will be noted that this school was overpaid 248 pupil days or based on the per capita rate at that time $183.87.
As the Auditor-General's Office has instructed that this adjustment be made on the June 1952 per capita grant payments, you are advised that the June earnings at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School were $12,616.44 less overpayment of $183.87, less part payment forwarded July 4, $6,000., net cheque $5,832.57.

It is presumed that this cheque will reach the school shortly.

Philip Phelan,
Superintendent of Education.
Province of MANITOBA

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter No. 282976*5 A. of date the 17th of August, 1920, re the purchase of some material required for the Sandy Bay Indian Boarding School.

The material for the repairs is at the school, but the Lay Brother Fafard, who does all the repairs at the school, is not in a shape to do them at the present time. He broke several of his ribs by falling on the seat of their traction engine, and in consequence he cannot use the material, as his health at the present time is very poor.

Father Chagnon the Principal desired me to ask the Department for a grant of $80.00 so that he can hire a mechanic to do this work at an early date.

I would recommend that the amount asked for be granted, and that Father Chagnon be asked to send in a voucher for labour to that amount.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Inspector of Indian Agencies,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ontario.

You will find enclosed the tender of a Winnipeg firm for the same material, with a total of $104.30.

The purchase of this material was authorized by your letter No. 252976-5 A., of date the 17th of August 1920.

Yours truly,

Extract from report of Mr. Insp. Jackson on the Sandy Bay Boarding School, October 16, 1920

The Sister Superior would like the Department to give her about 10 gallons of slate coloured paint for use in the dining room and kitchen. The sisters will put the paint on if it is given them. This paint would brighten up these rooms as they are in the basement and I would recommend that Agent Ogletree, at the town of Portage la Prairie, be authorized to send the paint to the address of Father Chagnon, which is Amaranth, Manitoba.

S. J. Jackson,
Insp. Indian Agencies.
Ottawa, December 9, 1920.

Sir,

Mr. Inspector Jackson, in his report on his recent inspection of the Sandy Bay Boarding School, requests that authority be granted to purchase ten gallons of slate coloured paint for use in painting the dining room and kitchen. He states that the Sisters will do the work of painting if the paint is supplied.

The Department will approve of the purchase of the above quantity of paint and you should consult the school authorities as to the colour required and you may then arrange for the purchase and forwarding of the above quantity. Before making the purchase, however, you should obtain competitive prices and purchase from the firm quoting you the lowest price. Properly certified vouchers, should be forwarded covering the expenditure incurred, to which should be attached a memorandum showing the firms asked for prices, as well as the prices quoted by them. Kindly give this matter your early attention. It is to be understood that there will be no cost involved to the Department for the labour performed in having the painting done.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

A. Ogletree, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
Portage la Prairie, Man.

Dear Sir:

Enclosed you will find voucher in duplicate in favour of the Marshall Wells Co. Ltd., Wholesale Hardware, of Winnipeg Manitoba, for the sum of $79.63.

This account is for a pair of hinges for the new door for the Boys playroom, and for 150 feet of boiler tubes.

The necessity for the purchase of these tubes is shown by the following extract from Father Chagnon's letter to me of the 8th of December, 1920.

"These two last winters, we have had no trouble at all with our big boiler, but Saturday the 4th, we had to put in 6 new tubes out of the 10 the Department supplied us a year ago, and 4 in the small boiler last summer, so we had no more on hand, therefore I am ordering 15 tubes today, so that in case of emergency we could keep on firing."

As these boilers get old it is always necessary to have some spare tubes on hand, and I would recommend that this account be paid.

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Inspector of Indian Agencies.

J. D. McLean, ESQ.,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,

Dear Sir,

Rev. Fr Chagnon of Marius, Man., wishes me to enclose copy of account for $81.25 with the following explanations.

The different items mentioned on this invoice were bought without authority from the Inspector, Mr. Jackson, but it being a case of absolute emergency Rev Fr Chagnon gave the order for boiler flues and hinges and wrote to Inspector S. J. Jackson as follows, on December 6th and later on December 29th:

"These two last winters we have had no trouble at all with our big boiler, but Saturday night we had to put in six new tubes out of the ten the Department had supplied us with a year ago and four in the small boiler during this last summer, so that we have no more on hand just now. I am ordering 15 tubes today so that in case of emergency we could keep on firing".

Herewith also our bill invoice in triplicate for one pair of double acting hinges for the inside door in the boys' playing room and fifteen boiler flues, these have been promptly ordered when three weeks ago we had to put in our last spare tube".
Since he has not heard from Mr. Jackson and was even under the impression that he was superannuated and therefore can not give attention to this matter, he has requested me to take up this question with the Department.

As this affair has been going on for over 5 months, I think that the Department will find in order to have this statement presented by me for payment and I hope that the latter will be made to Fr Chagnon, as requested.

Yours very truly,

Joseph Guy

Gentlemen:

At the request of your Mr Ogletree we journeyed to the above school and conducted a careful examination of the heating installation.

Our investigation revealed the fact that practically all of the fire brick both in the firebox and combustion chamber has been burned away and all that does remain is in very poor condition. A number of the tubes in the boiler are leaking and the balance do not seem to be in very good shape.

The "Father" in charge of the school complains about the north class-room being slow in heating.

The sink trap under the kitchen sink is in very poor condition.

Our recommendation to remedy the above defects are as follows:

1. Replace or reline fire box and the combustion chamber of the boiler with new fire brick.

2. Take out all the old tubes in the boiler and put in a complete set of new ones.

3. Change the connections of all the horizontal returns vent and drop each separately before connecting together to enter the boiler.

4. Install new heavy cast iron sink trap to kitchen sink.

The boiler installed is a 48x16 double return flue, tubular steam boiler having 67-3" tubes. Horizontal returns mentioned are three in number and two inches in size. Sink trap 1½" in size.

All repair work mentioned complete for the approximate sum of $942.50

Rev Father:

As requested by you, I have visited the building and examined the Boiler, Return pipe connections, to same, also the Brick setting for the Boiler, and be to report that the Brick-work is in very bad shape, requiring a new Fire-brick lining throughout, and that the Brick-work in general should be taken down and re-built.

Some of the Flues in the Boiler are leaking, and I also noticed that you have had some of these renewed, but I would recommend that the whole of the Flues be taken out, as the existing ones are in very bad condition, the Shell of the Boiler be properly cleaned and refit the Boiler with all new Tubes, also renew the Return connections entering the Boiler, as some of them are now leaking.

Re Water Supply Well.

Between the workshop and the Laundry Building outside, I would recommend that the Well, which is 20 feet deep and 7 feet in Diameter, be lined with Brick built in Cement Mortar, and fitted with re-inforced Concrete cover, also fitted with Manhole, 24" in Diameter and Cast Iron cover, and to be made level with the present ground.

The above is the report made after examining the School at Marius, P.O.

Yours Very Truly,

Joseph Turner

Reverend Sir,

I have to acknowledge receipt of yours of the 19th instant, advising us of the request of the Rev. Father O. Chagnon, principal of the Sandy Bay Boarding School, and enclosing a voucher and cancelled cheque for material supplied years ago in connection with the erection of an implement shed. The Reverend Principal is asking for a grant covering this expense.

I am directed to reply, whereas this building was erected in 1917, and that the appropriation for that fiscal year has been spent, and that no authority was granted from the Department at that time, that the Department believes this old account is not a charge on the financial resources for the current fiscal year.

The Department regrets that the Reverend Principal did not, before erecting the outbuilding in connection with the property which is Government-owned at Sandy Bay, secure authorization for the expenditure. It is the Government policy to repair our own buildings from time to time, and to erect any necessary outbuildings where the property is our own.

If any further information can be offered regarding the necessity for this expenditure and if any authority was given by the Department, at any time, we should be glad to hear further from the Rev. Principal.

Dear Sir,

Hoping you will extend your favor to my request and kindly recommend it to the Department of Indian Affairs, I give a statement of some improvements needed at Sandy Bay School; these improvements, of which you have seen by yourself the necessity, would be a great benefit for the institution.

1. Painting of the school, soldering of leaky save troughs, white washing of surrounding buildings. It is to be noted that the school has been painted last in 1913, so to delay this repair would mean much depreciation on the value of the building.

2. Increasing of pupilage from 60 to 70.

3. Repairs to granary near the school; joints floor shingle roof required. The building is 30' x 14'.

4. House for hired men. According experienced managers of Indian Boarding Schools, unmarried hired men working for these institutions are in many occasions a cause of trouble and worry for those in charge. At Sandy Bay School we have three hired men working by the year, two unmarried ones boarding in the school, the other with his family is living in a little log house near by. A house 30' x 20' according my opinion, would accommodate two small families and would answer the purpose. If this house is not built this year the little shanty will need a new looking and a shingle roof.

5. One oven (4 spinning wheels, wood stoves). We have still the small oven used at the opening of the school when pupils only were attending; now pupils being twice that number, a bigger oven would be needed. The J. J. Daout from St. Boniface would sell us the required size oven for $175.00.
I have just made an experiment in spinning yarn at home; it is a pastime for the girls now, and might be a benefit for them after their departure from school. 4 spinning wheels and 4 wool carders would cost at the T. Eaton Co. $53.50

6c Installation of telephone into school: This last improvement has been wanted for a long time. Often we had to go to Amaranth to send messages to call a doctor or send orders for repairs; it would save us many trips from the school to the station. The Manitoba Telephone System would do the job for $950.09; if we help them, their price would be $650.00.

If the Department is willing to go to the expense of the installation I believe the School could do the whole job for about $450.00 provided the Manitoba Telephone System do not change the price of poles: $2.50 at the nearest station.

I have to inform you that a new bake oven will be purchased by this Department, after competitive prices have been received and a minute number secured from the Purchasing Commission.

I regret to state that it will not be possible to provide new residence facilities for some of the employees at the Sandy Bay Indian Boarding School. A note has been made in this connection, however, and it may be possible to provide funds at the time of our next estimates. I have also to inform you that the Department cannot consider the installation of a telephone line, because of the expense involved. Further, this Department does not supply spinning wheels and wool carders.

In the principal's communication, one of the requests is for an increase in the pupilage at the school, and I have to inform you that provision has been made for an enrolment of 70, as from April first, 1923. Kindly intimate to the principal the nature of this communication.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Memorandum.

The Purchasing Commission of Canada:

We require, for the use of the Sandy Bay Boarding School, a portable bake oven having a capacity of approximately 100 - 1½ lb. loaves each baking. The last oven we purchased was in June, for the Lytton Industrial School, and was known as the No. 3 "Special Economy" portable oven, manufactured by Jean J. Daoust Limited, St. Boniface, Man.

In the past, we have obtained ovens for a number of our schools, after securing competitive prices, and the above firm have invariably received the order, as the oven manufactured by them is of much lighter material than that of the other manufacturers, and consequently, they can quote a lower price.

The oven needed for the Sandy Bay school is of the above type and is the same as was supplied to the Portage la Prairie, Mackay, Qu'Appelle, Fort Frances, Gordon's and Lytton schools during the past two years. The principals and staff of these schools have been quite satisfied with the work performed by this oven. The price of the No. 3 "Special Economy" oven, as manufactured by Jean J. Daoust Limited, will be approximately $260, delivered at Sandy Bay. I would be pleased to have your approval for making the purchase from this firm, without the necessity of obtaining prices from other manufacturers making a much heavier oven at a higher price.

F. H. Paget

Accountant & Purchasing Agent.

MEMO FOR FILE:

I visited the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School on the 10th and 11th of July, in company with Father Floride, of Winnipeg. The main building is in fair condition but needs painting. I understand that Mr. Bouyeron, the caretaker who was employed this same time ago, was about to commence the activity. The saw troughs need repairing. The outbuildings were good, with the exception of the main barn, which is old. Flooring is required for the hay loft (4000 ft. shiplap f. o. b. Amaranth). Two beds and mattresses suitable for guests are needed in the school.

I have made a note for the Estimates that a residence for the hired man is required. The main building is lighted by acetylene. The farm is small - only 50 acres is being cropped by the school. The management, however, uses 150 acres of Oblate property, which is 3 miles to the south. They have good agricultural machinery. The grounds around the buildings are ample but are not improved a great deal. The soil is not very suitable for lawn, shrubs, etc. Some ornamental fencing is required for the front garden and lawns.

I noticed that the plumbing was in urgent need of repairs in several important places in the building and I asked Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree to send a plumber up to estimate the cost of putting the water system in fair state of repair. If the expenditure is not too large, it should be attended to without delay.

I was very pleased with Father Chagnon. He is a hard working gentleman and has the interests of the school at heart. His assistant, Father Cordeau, is a splendid little chap and is an excellent worker among the pupils.

Supt. of Indian Education.

REGINA, SASK. November 8, 1924.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I have your letter of the 3rd instant, No. 126-9-5, informing me that the Church authorities have been pressing for years for a residence for the hired men at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, and that you had thought of making provision in the estimates for this, but that you now find you have funds available to do the work at once, and asking me to arrange to have the building erected.

I have no information whatever regarding this building other than your letter, although I visited the school within the period you mention. Inspector Christianson has also visited this institution two or three times, and he has never had the question brought to his attention by the Principal. Since your letter was received I called up our Agent at Portage la Prairie, and he informed me that he thought there were other things more important than this residence at the present time, and that the matter could stand.

Mr. Christianson is absent from the City today, but he has told me on different occasions about the very elaborate garage that was built at this institution some years ago, and which was not recommended by our Agent. If my memory serves me he told me that there was sleeping accommodation upstairs in this garage. This may be summer sleeping accommodation, I am not sure.

Duncan C. Scott,
Deputy Supt. General,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
Winter is now here and it will be just as difficult a matter building this house now as it would be a couple of months hence, and I would ask that the matter be deferred for the time being. I do not know what kind of a building should be erected, if a building at all. No building could be plastered in the dead of winter, nor could concrete be set for the foundation. I regret exceedingly that you cannot see your way clear to take the advice of your officers in the field, in matters of this kind. I cannot see how we can ever expect to have harmony when you deal over the heads of your own officers with the Church authorities, as you have been doing. It makes matters unpleasant for me. You have qualified Inspectors in this field, who are able to judge what should be done and what should not be done. Instead of referring to them, you depend in many cases entirely on the Church authorities and ignore your officers. I tried my very best for over a year to work in harmony with you in regard to this building. If your idea is that I should go ahead and spend money regardless of the necessity for doing so, this is another matter. Enough has been said about the foolish expenditures of money in connection with schools without bringing it up again.

Yours very truly,

W.M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

Dear Mr. Graham:

I am attaching hereto copy of a letter that came in from Mr. Scott today in connection with the erection of a residence for the school employees at Sandy Bay, in which he states that he would be glad if you would have inquiry made regarding the necessity for this building, and let him have a report.

In this connection I beg to say that I am really at a loss to know what the school authorities want this building for. Outside of the Sisters there are the two Fathers (one being the principal, and the other a missionary for the reserve), and a Brother. Two years ago they had a white man who is married to an Indian woman employed, but the last time I was there they just had a young halfbreed boy. The rest of the work, as far as I know, is done by the boys, and from time to time in busy seasons the school employs some of the ex-pupils but they live in their own homes on the reserve, coming to work in the morning and going home at night.

The amount of land farmed by the school on the reserve is about 100 acres; the balance of farming land being situated off the reserve along the Eastern boundary and, I would judge, about two and a half or three miles from the school. As far as my information goes this land belongs to the Church and there is a log house and stable on it.

W. M. Graham, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner,
Chateau Laurier,
Ottawa.
It may be that the Priests want to move their quarters out of the school. I cannot see that they need a house for the staff unless it is their intention to hire a married Farming Instructor, and that the house would provide accommodation for him.

If the Department will look up their files I believe that the argument advanced by the Principal when he was asking for the garage that was built at the school was that he wanted accommodation up over the garage in the way of sleeping quarters for men. The money was furnished for this building and it was erected according to his own plans. It may not be fitted up for winter accommodation, but it is certainly all right for summer, and as far as I can see the school is in no more need of extra accommodation for the staff at the present time than they have been ever since the school was built.

What is needed at this point more than anything else is extra school accommodation, as there are more children on the reserves than there is accommodation for and, if I remember correctly, the last time I was there Father Chagnon told me that he had a waiting list of about thirty.

I am giving you this information, thinking you would probably wish to discuss the matter with the Minister while you are there.

Yours very truly,

(Sgd.) M. Christianson.

Sir:

In connection with the house for the Farming Instructor at the Sandy Bay School. There was an appropriation of $2000.00 in the Estimates this year to cover this expenditure, and in August Inspector Christianson went down there for the purpose of arranging for the material etc. The plans which he had with him were for a house that we could have kept well within that figure, but the Principal was anxious to get a place large enough to accommodate two families. On his return the Inspector submitted this to me, and about the same time I had a communication from the Rev. Father Boys of St. Boniface, asking me, if possible, to endeavor to meet with the Principal's request, as they needed a house large enough to hold two families at the school. I then got out another bill of material and submitted it to Messrs. Brown & Rutherford, who were the lowest tenderers on the previous bill, and I found that the material for the present house would cost over $400.00 more than the material for the house which I had originally intended to build. However, as the season was advanced, and our men who had been building at the Little Sagkeehwan and Dog Creek Reserves were on their way over to Sandy Bay I could not do anything else but go on with the work. The Principal, however, agreed to do the handling, take out the excavation, and do the painting gratis with his own staff, and to give any other assistance possible in order to keep down the expense. At the present time I cannot just say what the additional cost will be, but it will be somewhere in the neighborhood of two or three hundred dollars. The erection of the house is well under way and will be finished in the course of a week or ten days.

I trust that my action in this matter will meet with the approval of the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W.M. Graham

Dear Mr. Graham:

SANDY BAY RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This school had been closed for the summer holidays and had just re-opened. About 60 children were present at the time of my visit and the rest were expected to arrive in a few days. Everything around the school was in good order.

They have been very unfortunate this year, their crop was practically a total failure on account of the dry weather. Their gardens, however, looked well and they will probably get sufficient potatoes and vegetables for their own use.

As you are aware, there is considerable repair work to be done at this institution and to get a price on this, I got Mr. Turner of the Standard Plumbing & Heating Co. Ltd., Winnipeg, who has previously done a lot of work at this school, to go up there with me and I am attaching herewith his tender for this work.

$800.00 was allowed by the Department for repairs in connection with the school and this amount will in no way be sufficient to meet the requirements. The work that I authorized while I was there was,- the deepening of the well at the stable. It had gone dry and the well driller had set his machine over the well and cleaned it out. This, however, did not start the flow of water, and from the lay of the land and other wells around there, it would be necessary to go through a limestone rock at the bottom of the well. As the well driller would have pulled away

I will also enumerate on the work figured on by Mr. Turner.

1. 5' x 5'6" galvanized iron tank. The water is pumped from the well up to tanks in the attic. The tank in question is one of three and the bottom is so badly rusted that it cannot be repaired. The eave-troughing also needs re-soldering. For this work and supplying a new tank his price is $116.00.
2. **Main Steam Boiler.** Installing new grate bars and arch plate and re-lining the side walls with fire brick, and point up brick-work on outside of boiler, repair defective water column, etc. I might say that the fire-box is in very poor shape; the grates are warped, and the brick side wall is badly tumbled down, and in its present shape it would probably not get through the winter. The price for this work and material is $198.00.

3. **Acetyline Gas Machine.** The school is lit up by Acetyline Gas. This machine is practically worn out and leaks gas as the carbide has eaten holes around the bottom rim of the machine. I would judge that it is very unsafe in its present condition. If this kind of a lighting system is to be continued a new machine is necessary; the cost is $225.00.

4. **Septic Tank.** The Septic Tank is about 200 ft. from the building and seems to have completely caved in. The concrete top and walls have all crumbled. The price on this is $614.00. This includes the making of a manhole between the building and the septic tank where the drains come from each side of the school into the main sewer. This, the Principal informs me, has often blocked up and they should have some means of cleaning this place out.

5. **Heating Pipes in Laundry.** These pipes were all leaking; eaten out with rust, etc., so badly that they cannot be repaired without replacing them with new pipes. The price for this work is $239.00.

The toilet and the drain pipes also seem to be badly clogged up and in another year it will probably be necessary to take down the drain pipe and clean them out. Some of the pipes will probably have to be replaced, but this is a big undertaking and a costly one.

The Principal is also asking for four washing machines and three wringers, which are certainly badly needed. The ones they have in the Laundry now are practically useless. These will cost about $100.00.

In the Department's letter dated the 16th June, advising you that $800.00 was available for repairs and replacements at this institution, they mentioned that the individual requests of the church authorities were gutters, inside staircase, foundation of exterior staircase, flooring of Boys' Recreation Room and flooring and ceiling of stable, and repairs to interior of ice house and some equipment for the laundry and dairy. The equipment for the Laundry, I have enumerated. A Cream Separator was required for the dairy, but the Principal has already purchased this and paid for it. The other articles mentioned have been attended to, with the exception of the flooring for the boys' recreation room. This is not needed, and flooring and ceiling for the stable is also not necessary. This has come up several times and I have always been under the impression that it was a waste of money putting additional flooring in the loft of the stable. This building is in very poor shape. The construction of the stable is of log
log framework and just lined on the outside with two ply of rough boards, no lining whatever on the inside. The foundation was of stone and mortar but the mortar has all pretty well washed away leaving the bare stones. On the West and North side of the building the foundation has rotted away badly and most of the boards from a foot up to two feet are all rotted. This is caused by no eave-troughing being on this side of the building and the water running down the boards and lying around the foundation. It will probably hang together for another winter but I certainly would not recommend any further expenditure on this building at the present time as it is going to be a very difficult job to repair the foundation, and until this is done it would not be wise to spend money on repairing the rest of the building. This is something that should be provided for in the estimates this year.

I consider that the repairs I have enumerated are absolutely necessary and in addition to this, it may be necessary to clean out some of the drains under the floor as the whole drain and sewerage system seems to have gone out of order.

PORTAGE LA PRAIRIE RESIDENTIAL SCHOOL.

This institution was also just re-opening after the holidays and about 80 children were present and they expected about 20 more to arrive this week. Everything in connection with this institution was in A1 shape and I never saw the place look better. They were just harvesting an excellent crop and Mr. Henry, the Principal, informed me that he expected to thresh about 6,000 bushels of grain. The summerfellow, gardens, etc., and the premises in general, are a credit to any institution.
institution.

A ventilating system was put in the barn last year with one ventilator on the roof; we find this is not sufficient, another one should be placed there to insure proper ventilation. Some of the steps in the stairs should also be replaced as a few of them are practically worn out. Mr. Henry will have these replaced if he is furnished with the material. There is about 14 steps that need replacing. I would ask that this expenditure be allowed.

Sir:-

I am in receipt of a letter from Mr. Indian Agent Ogletree, enclosing a copy of one received by him from the Rev. Principal of the Sandy Bay Boarding School, in which he makes a request to have a very large barn built, to accommodate 60 head of cattle and 20 head of horses.

I took this matter up with Mr. Inspector Christianson who is familiar with the situation at Sandy Bay, and who was referred to by the Principal as being aware of the conditions, and Mr. Christianson informs me he is of the opinion that, with an expenditure of from seven to eight hundred dollars at the outside, the existing barn could be made to give very good service for a number of years to come. The Inspector points out that the foundations under the north and east walls have more or less sunk and rotted away; these will have to be replaced by new timbers and cement and the building refloored. It would cost from four to six thousand dollars to build a new barn such as the Rev. Principal asks for, and from the information which I have I do not think the Department would be justified in incurring such an expenditure, especially in view of the fact that there is much more important work to be done.

I believe

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I believe that Mr. Mayoh, whom I have employed to do a great deal of our work, would be quite capable of going down next Spring and making a good job of this building if we had authority to do the work. There is no person in the Sandy Bay district who could undertake to do it, or who would make the money go as far as it should. My recommendation is that the Department place an amount of $800.00 in the Estimates for this purpose. It may not take this much money to complete the necessary work, but it is best to have a safe margin, and if there is a surplus it can be returned to the Department.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,

Dear Sir:

Replying to your letter of the 31st ultimo concerning an amount of $75.18, charged by us as an extra on the Septic Tank, constructed in connection with the building above noted, we would give you further explanation in the matter as it appears that previous letters could not have constituted a satisfactory submission.

The method of disposing of the effluent from the building was considered by us with Mr. Christianson of your staff in the Summer of last year, and it was decided that we should submit a proposal for constructing a reinforced concrete septic tank having general dimensions 12'-0" x 8'-0" x 10'-0" deep, with two compartments each having manholes and double cover, those being dimensions that Mr. Christianson decided on.

When we were considering this matter first at Sandy Bay, we were informed that the existing arrangements for sewer disposal were by means of a septic tank, but that the tank then in use had fallen in, and it was necessary to replace it by another. Thus it is, that the contract was duly entered into for the construction of a Septic Tank of the dimensions required by Mr. Christianson, according to our quotation included with other quotations in letter of August 20th last, addressed to Mr. Christianson, naming the cost of the septic tank at $614.00.

After we had completed our contract and had re-arranged the drains so as to cut off the old tank and have the effluent go into the new one, it was discovered that the old tank was not of septic tank design but merely used as a cesspool, and we also discovered that the nature of the ground was not suitable for the proper operation of a septic tank system of sewer disposal, because of the presence of ground water, which we have since learned, saturates the soil practically all the year round.

The new tank we would state was built in ground that was high lying in comparison with the old tank site.
Having completed our contract and become entitled to payment, we might have come away and left matters as satisfactorily completed according to instructions, but we felt that neither Mr. Christianson nor yourself when confronted with the real situation of affairs would appreciate it if we did not take advantage of the opportunity of re-arranging the outlets so that the effluent might overflow into the ground. This is the reason of our extra charge of $75.18, and we can do no other than stand by our claim.

Instead of letting this matter overflow through the opening near the top of the tank and mingle with the waters in the ground floor, we suggest that the tank be pumped out and contents removed to a point far away from the wells, or the source of water supply for building.

Our recommendation in letter of November 15th last to construct a second tank is to allow for the new tank existing to be completely covered over. The contents, after bacterial action has taken place, will leave the tank by way of the Syphon and enter the second tank, which from time to time can be emptied by pumping.

We submit the above explanation for your consideration. You will doubtless realize how that in untried sections of the country it is very difficult for any person to decide on what will be a thoroughly satisfactory method of sewerage disposal, for as in all other matters relating to human habitations, there have to be pioneers to discover what systems of construction are suitable for the different localities.

Our sub-contractor, R.M.Wyatt is pressing for payment of his bill, amounting to $75.18, and we trust that you will see your way clear to passing the item through the Department for payment. If it should want any further explanations, please let us know.

Yours truly,

THE STANDARD PLUMBING & HEATING CO. LTD.

In his letter of August 26th Mr. Johnston stated that the Department of Indian Affairs had as a result of unsatisfactory sewerage conditions at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School requested that engineers of this Branch make an inspection of the conditions and submit a report with estimates of costs for the overhauling of the sewerage system. Following this the writer and Mr. Rose visited Sandy Bay Indian Residential School during the week beginning September 12th and made the necessary survey and inspection of the work. The report which follows describes the present sewerage disposal system and recommends what work together with estimates of the cost is necessary to put the system into satisfactory working conditions.

PRESENT SEWAGE DISPOSAL SYSTEM.

Sandy Bay Indian Residential School is on the west side of Lake Manitoba in Township 18, Range 9, West of the Principal Meridian. The school, which is situated about one mile back from the shore of the lake, was opened in 1905 and the disposal of the sewerage at that time consisted in simply running the sewerage through an eight-inch tile down to a small creek which, as shown on the general layout plan, is located a short distance below the school. This system, although always giving a certain amount of trouble from odors, was in operation until 1913, when a concrete septic tank was installed a short distance above the creek, the affluent from this tank running into the creek. This system was in operation until the fall of 1926 when as the tank was being cleaned out the structure collapsed. A contract was then let to the Standard Plumbing and Heating Company for a new septic tank.
which was built in the late fall of 1926. The location of this tank which is now in use is shown on the accompanying plan. For a short time conditions appeared satisfactory but at the end of December, 1926, Father Chagnon, Principal of the School, stated that water started seeping up through the floor of the basement and though this condition to some extent passed away, trouble again occurred from this cause in June and July of this year, the rise of water in the basement floor becoming so pronounced that the school authorities were instructed by the Department of Indian Affairs to uncover all the outside sewer pipe and the septic tank in order, if possible, to discover the cause of the trouble. At the time of the visit the tile drains and tank were uncovered and open for inspection and showed that the sewer pipes were three-quarters full of solids; the pipes in poor condition, a number being broken; that the eight-inch tile leading to the septic tank was reduced to a three-inch pipe of entry into the tank, and that owing to settlement of the ground or some other cause the connection at the tank was broken. The disposal of the sewage under these conditions was very unsatisfactory, the sewage slowly seeping away through the pipes and through the broken connection into the septic tank and from there through a short tile drain down to the ditch leading to the creek. There is very little breaking up of the solid matter, the sewage gradually draining into the ditch and creek and causing a very bad odor.

It was not possible to make an examination of the drain pipe under the basement floor of the school and it is assumed that though these pipes may be partially filled with solids that they are in good condition.
PROPOSED ALTERATIONS AND ADDITIONS.

The disposal system as recommended has been decided on in view of the following considerations:

1. The ground from the school towards the lake has very little fall and is not favorable for a modern sewage disposal system at a moderate cost.

2. Though it is considered that the present septic tank is too small for the proper treatment of the sewage from an institution as large as the school, it was thought advisable that in view of its recent installation that some use if possible should be made of it in the proposed system.

3. The source of the drinking water for the school is rain water and not from wells, so that there is no danger of contamination from disposing of unpurified sewage in the ground.

4. It was advisable if possible to provide a system that would do away with the disposal of semi-purified sewage into the small creek as with the small available fall the sewage practically seeps away causing, during the warm weather, disagreeable odors.

In view of the above it is proposed to utilize the present tank and run the effluent from it into a large cesspool located immediately below. The present septic tank is a concrete structure with a settling chamber 5 feet by 6 feet by 10 feet deep. From this chamber the sewage flows through a dividing wall through a three inch pipe into a siphon chamber, though no siphons have been installed. Though, as already stated, this tank is too small for the proper breaking up of the solids it still will effect a certain action along this line and in combination with a cesspool should give a fairly satisfactory disposal of the sewage.

The cesspool proposed would be 25 feet long by 10 feet wide with a concrete bottom and wooden sides and roof, and as shown on the attached plan it would be located about 20 feet below the present septic tank. To avoid undue maintenance costs all lumber used in the tank is to be...
creosoted. The roof would be placed about one foot below the ground so that there would be no unsightly structures showing. Two man-holes in the roof reaching to the ground level would give necessary access to the tank for cleaning or other purposes. By use of the cesspool any disagreeable odors which have been experienced in the past would be done away with as the sewage instead of trickling away into the creek would by use of the cesspool gradually drain away underground.

The present tile pipes are in such condition that it is necessary to relay all these pipes with new tile at proper grade. In replacing the eight-inch tile six-inch will be used as this size will easily handle the sewage from the school. As shown on the general layout plan it is also proposed to have two man-holes, one immediately outside the building on the right branch of the sewer pipe leading from the school. This man-hole is considered necessary as at this point the foundation drain running around the school is connected to the sanitary sewer and according to Father Chaganon due to the rats, a certain amount of earth is carried from this drain into the sanitary sewer. With a manhole located at this point the foundation drain can be trapped in the man-hole and the danger of earth being carried into the sanitary sewer overcome. The other man-hole will be located at the junction of the two drains from the school and from this man-hole the sewer will run direct to the septic tank, thus doing away with the right angle bend which now occurs just before the sewer pipe enters the septic tank. The small three-inch pipe connecting the sewer to the septic tank will also be replaced by one of proper size, as it is considered that this has had quite a bit to do with the retarding of the sewage and causing a gradual blocking up.
In addition to the above the sewer pipes under the basement floor of the school should be thoroughly flushed and cleaned by a plumber as no doubt due to outside stoppage of flow these pipes will be badly choked.

With the cleaning out of the sewer pipes underneath the basement floor, the replacing of the pipes outside the school, proper connections to the septic tank, and with the cesspool installed as described above, a satisfactory disposal of the sewage should be accomplished. On account of the small size of the septic tank it will probably be necessary to remove the solids every six months, but the cleaning out of the cesspool will probably not have to be done more than once in three or four years.

The disposal of the sewage in the manner above described is only allowable in view of the fact that the drinking water for the school is not obtained from wells but from rain water which is collected in a large concrete tank outside the school. For this reason it is not necessary to take into account the contamination of the ground water by sewage which has not been properly purified.

Sir:

Re - Sandy Bay Indian Residential School Sewerage System.

Enclosed you will please find accounts in triplicate of Mr. Alfred Babb for the overhauling of the sewerage system at the Sandy Bay Indian School. This work, which was authorized in your letter of October 6th, comprises the re-laying of the outside drains to the septic tank, the cleaning out of the pipes in the basement and the building of the man-holes recommended in Mr. Craig's report of September 26th. Mr. Babb, in his letter accompanying the accounts, requests that payment for this work may be made as promptly as possible, and in view of the comparatively large outlay for the small profit due him I would be obliged if a cheque covering this account be forwarded at an early date. In forwarding this cheque, please have the Department of Indian Affairs transmit it through this office.

Though the building of the cess-pool has been left over until next year, as instructed, the school authorities should have no trouble in the disposal of their sewage in the meantime. With reference to the estimate for the cess-pool as given in Mr. Craig's report, I wish to point out that at the time the estimate was made a price of $80.00 per thousand feet board measure for creosoted lumber was secured from the local representative of the creosoting company in Calgary. Sometime afterwards, however, I was advised that this price of $80.00 per thousand should be increased to $110.50 per thousand, as the price first submitted had been corrected by the creosoting company in Calgary. As 4,000 feet of creosoted lumber are called for this will increase the estimate for the cess-pool by $122.00.

Your obedient servant,

C. H. Attwood,
District Chief Engineer.

Dear Sir:

I have received a letter from Reverend Father Guy referring to the probable estimates for our Indian Residential Schools, and I have noticed with regret that the Sandy Bay School will get credit only for sewage disposal. But as a sum of $800.00 has already been authorized for repairs of the stable, and as the work was not proceeded with, it seems that no new appropriation was made for Sandy Bay.

Reverend Father Chagnon, Principal of Sandy Bay School, not being aware that Rev. Father Guy was going to Ottawa, has written Oct. 7th to Mr. Agent Ogletree asking him to submit to the Department the following requirements:

a) New stable for 60 heads of cattle, 20 horses and 200 chickens. Lumber could be hauled from Amaranth Station to School, 7 miles at a rate of $2.50 per thousand, provided hauling takes place in winter.

b) Maple flooring for boys' recreation 30 by 40.

c) Medal Laundry Washing Machine, $17.75 at Eaton's Winnipeg.

d) About 1000 ft of one inch lumber to make cupboard from floor to ceiling in sewing Room.

Reverend Father Chagnon has repeatedly during the last three years petitioned for a new stable. He thought that to repair the old one was a mere waste of money, and this was also the opinion of Mr. Graham, as may be inferred from his letter of August 18th, 1927.

With reference of the amount of $800.00 authorized for repairs to the stable at your School, writes Mr. Graham, it is a question in my mind as to whether this work should be proceeded with or not, as I am doubtful whether the building would warrant spending this money on it, and it might be better to erect a new building. I am not saying that we should, but the matter will be thoroughly looked into and if you can get along during the coming winter, as I am told you can, with the existing stable, I will have an opportunity of getting into the matter before the estimates are prepared.

The estimates have been prepared and nothing is provided. The Reverend Principal told me it is more than doubtful whether the old stable would stand for another year. I hope it is not too late to have the Sandy Bay School requirements included in the supplementary estimates.

Yours truly,

I have acknowledged receipt of your letter of the 12th instant #126-9-5 informing me that the Church authorities are pressing for the early erection of a new stable at the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School. You express the opinion that it is not necessary to build a barn to house 50 head of cattle and 20 head of horses, and I may say that I agree with you. We do not provide stabling for half this number of stock at any school in the West, and it is not the intention to allow them to keep so many.

In regard to the existing barn at the Sandy Bay School, this matter has been under discussion for some considerable time, and I have again taken it up with Inspector Christianson today, who is quite familiar with the situation, and to use his own expression - "It would be a positive shame to discard this building." He describes it as being a very large barn, the skeleton built of spruce logs and sided with two thicknesses of common lumber, and covered with lumber and metallic roofing. The back and one end of this building have become somewhat deteriorated, owing to the fact that manure has been piled against it to keep the building warm, and this has rotted away the lumber to some extent. The Inspector thinks it will be necessary to have it re-sided, and parts of the stone and cement foundation will require repairing.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Inspector
Inspector Christianson, on the occasion of his next visit to the agency, will take with him a practical builder and will see just what can be done to put the building in shape.

I feel that the authorities of this school have heard what is going on in the way of building at other points and it is just a matter of wanting to have something as good as the other man, because they would never discard this building if the Government were not to be called upon to pay for the erection of a new one. No white farmer would think of abandoning a building of this kind, and I do not think the Department is called upon to spend money to replace buildings that are still serviceable. I certainly cannot recommend a new building, in view of the information I have before me.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

SANDY BAY BOARDING SCHOOL

As I have reported on this school several times it will not be necessary for me to say much in this lengthy report, as things are about the same. Everything was in good order, both inside and out. The crop was looking well and the garden was in excellent shape. I believe that as far as the work in the school is concerned it is carried on satisfactorily, and Father Chagnon is always willing to co-operate with the Department, but one thing is plain, and that is that as far as the Indians are concerned on the reserve the influence of the school is not noticeable. The school may not be so much at fault in this regard, of course, as conditions in the past have been so bad on the reserve that in all probability it would not matter how good the influence of the school was, the bad influence on the reserve would predominate, and the children coming out from the school simply fall in with the rest of the gang as soon as they are turned loose.

I do not wish to be unfair to the Principal, as he has always endeavored to co-operate with us; at the same time, he is not the same type as the Principal at Pine Creek, and does not command the same respect from the Indians.

As regards the fire protection at this institution, I might say that the fire hose are absolutely rotten, and I have asked that the school be supplied with four new ones. They have sufficient fire extinguishers, but the hose must be replaced. There is a similar arrangement here as at Pine Creek, a door opens from the dormitories out on to a platform, which has a sliding pole leading to the ground. Fire drill is held once a week, and when the hose are renewed I think that every precaution will have been taken to protect this school against fire.

MEMORANDUM:-

MR. C. H. Attwood.

Re - Construction of Cesspool at Sandy Bay Indian School.

Following the submittal of Mr. Craig's report dated September 26, 1927, on the sewage disposal system of the Sandy Bay Indian Residential School, the Department of Indian Affairs decided to have certain alterations and repairs made and a cesspool constructed as recommended by Mr. Craig. The alterations and repairs were completed last fall and the cesspool was constructed during August under the supervision of the undersigned.

Arrangements were made with Mr. P. H. Hancock, building contractor, of Portage la Prairie, to construct the cesspool on the basis of cost plus a sum of Fifty Dollars. Wages were paid and materials purchased by this office. The work was started on August 21st and completed on the 25th.

The cesspool, which is a frame structure built of 3" lumber, is located on the discharge pipe from the septic tank. The overall dimensions of the cesspool are 10' x 25' x 7' high. It is constructed below the ground level and is provided with a manhole. The roof is painted with a coat of coal tar and covered with a foot of earth. The details of the framing of the structure are shown on the attached blue print.

The cost of constructing the cesspool was Four Hundred and Seventy-one and 63/100 Dollars which was disturbed as follows:

In further reference to your letter of June 2 authorizing the carrying out of certain improvements to the sewage system at the Sandy Bay Indian school in Manitoba, I enclose herewith a report from Mr. E.B. Patterson, the engineer who superintended the work, describing the construction of the repairs which have been carried out.

The total cost as shown by the accounts which are enclosed herewith in duplicate amounts to $471.63, while the estimated cost was in the vicinity of $760. The difference is due mainly to the elimination of the creosoted lumber and to dispensing with the concrete floor for the cesspool. The reason for not using creosoted lumber was because the creosoting had to be done at Calgary and no lumber company would give delivery except upon a date two months after receipt of order, which would have made the completion of the job impossible this year. The district engineer reports that the nature of the soil did not require the placing of a concrete floor.

Due to the reduced cost of construction there is a credit balance of $288.37 in the Bank of Montreal at Winnipeg and I shall be glad to know whether to refund this money to the Department of Indian Affairs or allow it to remain until the end of the fiscal year in case additional expenditures are required for other Indian schools in the Winnipeg district.

Your obedient servant,

Director.

Dear Sir:

Acting under your instructions to examine the plumbing at the Indian School at Sandy Bay. We made the trip up to Sandy Bay and made an inspection of the plumbing in the building.

On examination we find that the pipes were very badly corroded, some of the pipes being practically filled. This is caused from the nature of the water, and it would be quite impossible to give you a definite figure for repairing same. In our opinion the only way that this job could be done satisfactorily would be to do it on a percentage basis, charging you for what new material was required and time. Even if you had an Architect or a Plumbing Engineer examine same he could not give you any more information as it is quite impossible to find out just what condition these pipes are in until same are taken down, and where the pipes are very badly corroded it would be much cheaper to put in new pipes than attempt to clean the old ones.

If you give us instructions to go ahead with this job we will ship the material that we think is necessary to Sandy Bay and will use all old material that we find suitable, replacing the ones that are badly corroded with new pipes. Regarding the time it would take, I presume that it would take in the neighbourhood of four weeks for two men.

It will be necessary to replace one or two of the closet bowls as we find these are cracked.

Awaiting your further instructions. We remain,

Yours truly,

[Signature]

Dear Mr Waite;-

Following out your instructions Re the plumbing at Sandy Bay, we had Mr Grassie and another plumber go to Sandy Bay. Re the Hot Water Tank. On examination we find that there would have to be at least a new end put on same. This would have to be taken down and shipped into Winnipeg in order to do this. What would be more satisfactory, however, would possibly be to buy a new tank, and instead of the coils being ordinary galvanized pipe on the inside, as they are now, brass coils would be very much better, and would give longer service, on account of the conditions of the water at this particular point.

Another thing we noticed when we were on the roof was that the shingles in some places were entirely off and would need immediate attention. We were not asked to inspect the roof, but we are making this notation.

Dear Sir,

I respectfully beg to advise you that in the drilling of the well on the Indian Reserve, Sandy Bay, Amaranth I have encountered serious and unforeseen difficulties.

At 52 ft I tapped a vein of salty water, at 122 ft another of similar quality, and at 127 ft I struck quicksand. Below this there is a stratum of limestone rock with excellent water, but of insufficient supply. From this depth onward I had intense trouble to cope with the invasion of quicksand and salty water. To prevent or check the invasion I had to resort to the use of cement, which is the principle in cases of this kind, but all to no purpose.

Finally, owing to the invasion of this quicksand my well caved and in my
Efforts to release the same I took my new cable, thereby losing my complete set of tools, and consequently am now unable to proceed further with the well.

I feel satisfied that had I been able to sink lower I would have met with water of excellent quality.

The Rev. Father Chagnon, Principal, is extremely anxious that I remain here and make yet another attempt to get water, but without tools I am unable to accomplish anything and being but a poor man cannot bear the expense of a new set as I have lost heavily in this untoward happening.

It is through no fault of mine, nor any negligence that the tools were lost and I humbly suggest that the Indian Department provide me with the tools to replace the lost ones, to enable me to proceed with the work, and that the Department bear the cost of such equipment.

I am hopeful of being able to remove the large casing as I have already raised it a matter of three feet.

Trusting that you will give this matter your immediate attention, I remain

Yours very faithfully,

Wm. A. Smith

Sir:

I beg to inform you that a fair quality of water has been found at the Sandy Bay Residential School. The water is a little salty, but the Reverend Principal is quite satisfied with the quality, which is vastly superior to any in the vicinity of the school. I have forwarded a sample to the Bacterial Department, Department of Public Welfare for testing purposes and will forward the result of the test as soon as I am in receipt of same. I have also instructed the driller to pump the well with a power pump until the 8th of December; this will clear the water and prove an ample supply. I request permission to go ahead with the work of piping the water from the well to the school, providing a sufficient flow of water is on hand, of which I have very little doubt. I beg to suggest that a new wind-mill be purchased together with the tower, the old mill is practically worn out, the legs are set in cement, which would make the moving a big job and the mill is not worth it. The mill would be very useful in pumping water to the hog pastures. It would also be very useful in case of fire. Approximate 200 feet of 2" pipe will be required, together with cement and lumber, and the labour of digging a trench to a depth below frost line, also the labour of erecting the wind-mill etc., laying and connecting the pipe line. The estimates given are approximate. I have asked Mr Smith for an estimate covering the cost of all labour less materials. I will ask two plumbers in the City here for estimates as soon as authority is granted to go ahead with the work.

One 3' Vaneless mill complete with 40' tower and braces, legs etc. $150.00
200 feet of galvanized pipe @ .25 50.00
Lumber & cement for cribbing and pipe line 75.00
Labour, digging trench 6' deep and erection of mill etc. 200.00

The Best Deputy Secretary,
